‚ñ∂ Arrival: They will come to the caster‚Äôs location as fast as they can.
‚ñ∂ Comprehension: They understand the caster‚Äôs words while the spell lasts.
‚ñ∂ Aid: They will aid the caster in whatever way they can.
‚ñ∂ If the caster is being attacked: The summoned animals will attack the enemy, only fleeing if they fail a morale check.
‚ñ∂ If the caster is not being attacked: Summoned animals will usually flee if harmed.
‚ñ∂ Once an animal flees: The spell is broken for that animal.

The caster can control the surrounding temperature in a limited radius.
‚ñ∂ Temperature range: The temperature may be raised or lowered up to the full, range of temperature variance in the natural world. (e.g. down to arctic cold or up to tropical heat.)
‚ñ∂ Control: The caster can adjust the temperature at will while the spell lasts.

The caster enters into a trance of communion with the natural world.
‚ñ∂ During the trance: Over 1 turn, one fact about the surrounding land is revealed to the caster per experience level.
‚ñ∂ Facts: Knowledge of one of the following, in a certain direction: the terrain, bodies of water, plants, animals, minerals, or resident intelligent creatures.
‚ñ∂ Restrictions: The spell has no effect if cast underground or in a non-natural environment.

By concentrating (no movement allowed), the caster causes one of the following conditions to manifest around them. This spell only functions outdoors.
‚ñ∂ Calm: Clears bad weather (though side-effects‚Äîe.g. mud after rain‚Äîremain.)
‚ñ∂ Extreme heat: Dries up snow or mud (including transmute rock to mud). Creatures in the area move at half normal rate.
‚ñ∂ Fog: Visibility drops to 20‚Äô. Creatures in the fog move at half their normal rate. At the referee‚Äôs option, they may also have a chance of getting lost.
‚ñ∂ High winds: Movement rates are halved. Missile fire and flight are impossible. High winds may be used to increase the sailing speed of ships by 50% if they travel with the wind. In sandy areas, may cause a sandstorm, reducing visibility to 20‚Äô.
‚ñ∂ Rain: ‚Äì2 penalty to missile attacks. Mud forms in 3 turns, halving movement rates.
‚ñ∂ Snow: Visibility drops to 20‚Äô. Movement rates are halved. Bodies of water may freeze. After the snow thaws, mud remains and still impedes movement.
‚ñ∂ Tornado: The caster can direct the tornado, which moves at 120‚Äô per round. The tornado can be directed to attack (see 'Tornado' in the Monsters section for stats). Ships caught in a tornado have a 75% chance of suffering 12 points of hull damage.

The caster steps into a tree, then instantly steps out of a tree of the same species in another location. The trunks of both trees must be large enough for the caster to fit inside.
Distance: The maximum distance between the two trees depends on their type:
‚ñ∂ Oak: 600 yards
‚ñ∂ Ash, elm, linden, yew: 360 yards
‚ñ∂ Other deciduous trees: 300 yards
‚ñ∂ All other trees: 240 yards

An invisible barrier is conjured around the caster‚Äôs person, preventing contact by either plants or animals.
‚ñ∂ Plants or animals: When this spell is cast, the caster must choose whether the barrier is effective against plants (including plant-like monsters) or animals (normal and giant-sized but excluding fantastic creatures or those of greater than animal intelligence).
‚ñ∂ range: The magical barrier extends merely an inch from the caster‚Äôs body.
‚ñ∂ Life-forms of the selected type: Cannot touch or physically attack the caster.
‚ñ∂ Caster‚Äôs attacks: The caster cannot touch or attack affected life-forms except by using spells.
‚ñ∂ A barrier of protection from plants: May be used to clear a path through dense undergrowth. The path may then be used by others.

This spell turns up to 3,000 square feet of rock into 10‚Äô deep mud.
‚ñ∂ Movement: Any creatures passing through the mud have their movement rate reduced by 90%.
Reversed: Transmute Mud to Rock
Changes an area of mud‚Äîup to 3,000 square feet and up to 10‚Äô deep‚Äîinto rock. This alteration is permanent.

Changes an area of mud‚Äîup to 3,000 square feet and up to 10‚Äô deep‚Äîinto rock. This alteration is permanent.
Reversed: Transmute Rock to Mud
This spell turns up to 3,000 square feet of rock into 10‚Äô deep mud.
‚ñ∂ Movement: Any creatures passing through the mud have their movement rate reduced by 90%.

A barrier of tough, thorny plants is conjured at a point of the caster‚Äôs choosing.
‚ñ∂ Size: The wall can be any size up to 1,200 square feet and may be shaped in any manner and to any dimensions the caster desires (e.g. it may be a straight wall or curved into a protective circle).
‚ñ∂ Enveloping creatures: Any creatures standing in a spot where the wall is conjured suffer damage equal to 1d8 plus their AC score.
‚ñ∂ Pushing through: Creatures may push through the wall, but suffer damage equal to 1d8 plus their AC score for every 10‚Äô.
‚ñ∂ Ascending AC: If using the optional rule for Ascending Armour Class (see Old-School Essentials Classic Fantasy), the damage inflicted by the thorns is 1d8 + (19 ‚Äì AAC score).
‚ñ∂ Hacking through the wall: Is possible and does not inflict damage on those breaking through. It takes 4 turns to chop through a 10‚Äô section.
‚ñ∂ Fire: The wall is unharmed by normal fire, but magical fire will burn it away completely in 2 turns.

Illusionist.description:
A sound of the caster‚Äôs choosing is conjured, emanating from a point anywhere within range.
‚ñ∂ Motion: The sound may move as long as it remains within range.
‚ñ∂ Change: The sound may change and evolve over the course of the duration as the caster wishes.
‚ñ∂ Loudness: The loudness of the sound is limited by the caster‚Äôs level: a maximum equivalent to approximately four humans shouting per experience level. (For example, a horde of rats is equal to 8 humans, a lion roaring is equal to 16 humans, a dragon roaring is equal to 24 or more humans.)

This spell conjures an orb of pure colour that shoots towards a visible target within range.
‚ñ∂ Colour: The caster may conjure an orb of one of the colours listed in the 'Chromatic Orb Effects' table, depending on their experience level and the gems available.
‚ñ∂ Gemstone: The colour orb is created by refracting and amplifying the pure hue and intrinsic properties of a gemstone, which must be in the caster‚Äôs possession. Casting chromatic orb does not cause the gemstone to be consumed.
‚ñ∂ Value: The gem to be used must be of a certain minimum value (indicated in the 'Chromatic Orb Effects' table).
‚ñ∂ Hit: The orb hits unerringly, inflicting damage on the target and another effect that depends on its colour.

A flurry of clashing, rainbow-hued colours erupts from the caster‚Äôs hand.
‚ñ∂ Targets: 1d6 creatures in the area of effect.
The effect: Depends on the HD of each target, relative to the caster:
‚ñ∂ HD less than or equal to caster: Knocked unconscious for 2d4 rounds. (Creatures of 6HD or greater may save versus spells.)
‚ñ∂ HD up to 2 greater than caster: Save versus spells or be blinded for 1d4 rounds. A blind creature cannot attack.
‚ñ∂ HD 3 or more greater than caster: Save versus spells or be unable to move, attack, or make other actions for one round.
Creatures that cannot see: Are unaffected by this spell.

Lights under the caster‚Äôs control are conjured and may be directed to move anywhere within range. The caster may choose to conjure one of the following types of light:
1. Torches: 1‚Äì4 lights that resemble torches or lanterns, casting the appropriate volume of light.
2. Spheres: 1‚Äì4 glowing spheres, resembling will-o-the-wisps.
3. Humanoid: A single, glowing, humanoid form.

Illusionist.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Illusionist.description: The subject can see through illusions within 10‚Äô per level of the caster. Invisible creatures or objects in the same range are also revealed.

The caster is wrapped in an illusion, taking on the outward appearance of another humanoid. Two variants are possible, chosen as the spell is cast:
1. Imagined form: The caster takes on a form which they imagine.
2. Duplicate individual: The caster copies the form of a living individual whom they touch. An attack roll is required if the target is unwilling.
Stipulations: The following apply:
‚ñ∂ Height: The illusionary form may be at most 1‚Äô taller or shorter than the caster‚Äôs normal form.
‚ñ∂ Weight: Apparent weight may be altered in any way.
‚ñ∂ Gear: Clothing or items may be altered in any way.
‚ñ∂ Observers: If the spell is used to copy another‚Äôs appearance, those familiar with the copied individual may save versus spells to detect the ruse.

The caster‚Äôs gestures and droning syllables open the minds of one or more subjects within range to a hypnotic suggestion that is uttered as part of the spell casting.
‚ñ∂ Number of targets: Up to 1d6 creatures are affected. The number of creatures affected is determined after the suggestion is made.
‚ñ∂ Wording: The suggestion must take the form of a short phrase (at most one or two sentences) suggesting a course of action to the subjects.
‚ñ∂ Comprehension: A language that is understood by the subjects must be used.
‚ñ∂ Harmful suggestions: A suggested course of action that is obviously harmful to a subject causes the spell to automatically fail for that subject.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: Each subject may save versus spells to resist the hypnotic suggestion. If the save fails, the subject will follow the caster‚Äôs suggestion for up to the duration of the spell.
‚ñ∂ Reasonable suggestions: A suggestion that is worded in such a way to make it sound very reasonable incurs a ‚Äì2 penalty to the saving throw.
Restrictions: Undead are not affected by hypnotism.

This spell has three usages:
1. Conjuring light: In a 15‚Äô radius. The magical light is sufficient for reading, but is not as bright as daylight. The spell may be cast upon an object, in which case the light moves with the object.
2. Blinding a creature: By casting the spell upon its eyes. If the target fails a saving throw versus spells, it is blinded for the duration. A blind creature cannot attack.
3. Cancelling darkness: Light may cancel a darkness spell.

Creates a 15‚Äô radius area of magical blackness, preventing normal sight (but not infravision). Like light, it may alternatively be used to blind creatures or to dispel a light spell.
Reversed: Light
This spell has three usages:
1. Conjuring light: In a 15‚Äô radius. The magical light is sufficient for reading, but is not as bright as daylight. The spell may be cast upon an object, in which case the light moves with the object.
2. Blinding a creature: By casting the spell upon its eyes. If the target fails a saving throw versus spells, it is blinded for the duration. A blind creature cannot attack.
3. Cancelling darkness: Light may cancel a darkness spell.

A visual illusion of the caster‚Äôs choosing manifests in a 20‚Äô cube area. Three types of illusions may be created:
1. An illusionary monster: That can be directed to attack. The monster has AC 9 [10] and vanishes if hit in combat.
2. An illusionary attack: For example, an avalanche, a falling ceiling, a magic missile, etc. Targets who save versus spells are unaffected.
3. A scene: Either changing the appearance of the affected area or creating the appearance of something new. The scene disappears if touched.
Stipulations: The following apply:
‚ñ∂ Concentration: Is required to maintain the illusion. If the caster moves or loses concentration, the spell ends.
‚ñ∂ Illusionary monsters or attacks: May appear to be harmful but never inflict real damage. A character who appears to die actually falls unconscious, a character turned to stone will actually be paralysed, and so on. Such effects last for 1d4 turns.
‚ñ∂ Illusions from imagination: If the illusion is of something the caster has not personally seen, the referee should grant targets a bonus to any applicable saving throws.

By means of read magic, the caster can decipher magical inscriptions or runes as follows:
‚ñ∂ Scrolls: The magical script of a scroll of arcane spells can be understood. The caster is then able to activate the scroll at any time in the future.
‚ñ∂ Spell books: A spell book written by another arcane spell caster can be deciphered.
‚ñ∂ Inscriptions: Runes or magical words inscribed on an object or surface can be understood.
‚ñ∂ Reading again: Once the caster has read a magical inscription using read magic, they are thereafter able to read that particular writing without recourse to the use of this spell.

The caster gestures threateningly at an intelligent target within range.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: The target may save versus spells to avoid coming under the spell‚Äôs effect.
‚ñ∂ An afflicted target: Perceives the caster as a monster from its worst nightmares and will flee from the caster at maximum speed.
‚ñ∂ Breaking the spell: The target may make a new save versus spells each round with success indicating that the spell is broken. Until the spell is broken, the target believes it is being pursued by the imagined horror.
Restrictions: Undead and creatures of less than animal intelligence are not affected.

A wall of roiling vapour is conjured at a location of the caster‚Äôs choosing within range.
‚ñ∂ Area: The fog fills a 10‚Äô cube area per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Vision: The fog blocks normal vision and infravision.
‚ñ∂ Strong winds: Can clear the fog before the spell‚Äôs duration has expired.

A single creature is afflicted by a phantasm which nullifies either its visual or aural sensory input (as selected by the caster), rendering it blind or deaf.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: The target may save versus spells to avoid the phantasm.
‚ñ∂ Removing: As the blindness or deafness caused by this spell is illusory, it cannot be removed by magic that cures disease. The affliction may be removed by spells that dispel magic or illusions.
‚ñ∂ Cancelling: The caster may cancel the spell‚Äôs effect at will.

The caster‚Äôs form becomes blurry and wavering.
‚ñ∂ Attack penalties: Creatures attacking the caster suffer a ‚Äì4 penalty to hit. This penalty is reduced to ‚Äì2 on a creature‚Äôs second or subsequent attempts to hit the caster.
‚ñ∂ Save bonus: The caster gains a +1 bonus to saving throws against magic that directly targets them.
Enchanted objects, areas, or creatures are caused to glow. Both permanent and temporary enchantments are revealed.

The aura of a creature or object is veiled.
‚ñ∂ Detection spells: (e.g. detect magic, detect evil) are deflected, revealing another creature or object nearby.
‚ñ∂ Divination spells: (e.g. know alignment) cast upon the subject reveal the opposite to the truth.

This spell causes a single creature to perceive the caster‚Äîwhatever their normal appearance‚Äîas utterly captivating.
‚ñ∂ Restrictions: Creatures of less than animal intelligence are not affected.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: The subject may save versus spells to avoid the effect.
Affected subjects: Behave as follows:
‚ñ∂ Besotted: The subject follows the caster wherever they go, as if besotted, unless doing so would present a serious danger.
‚ñ∂ Obedience: If the caster can communicate with the subject (even if only by gestures), it may obey requests. Each time a request is made of the subject, the caster must make a CHA check (possibly penalised, if the request is against the nature or best interests of the subject). If the check fails, the spell is broken and the target‚Äôs perception of the caster becomes one of horror, rage, and hate.
‚ñ∂ Animals: An animal remains fascinated for 1d4 days, after which it may either attack the caster (if it has been mistreated) or simply leave. If the caster treated the animal well, there is a percentage chance equal to the caster‚Äôs CHA that the animal will henceforth remain by the character‚Äôs side of its own free will.

A pattern of twisting, interweaving colours fills the air in a 30‚Äô √ó 30‚Äô area centred on the caster.
‚ñ∂ Creatures that see the pattern: Must save versus spells or become hypnotised as long as they are able to watch the pattern.
‚ñ∂ Number of creatures affected: Up to 24HD of creatures may be hypnotised.
‚ñ∂ Hypnotised creatures: Simply stand still, gazing at the pattern of colours.
‚ñ∂ If a hypnotised creature is harmed: The pattern ceases to enthral it and it may act next round.
Concentration: The caster can maintain the pattern indefinitely as long as they concentrate on the spell and remain stationary.

An illusion of the caster‚Äôs choosing‚Äîincluding minor sounds (though not speech)‚Äîmanifests in a 20‚Äô cube area. Three types of illusions may be created:
1. An illusionary monster: That can be directed to attack. The monster has an Armour Class of 7 [12] and will vanish if hit in combat.
2. An illusionary attack: For example, an avalanche, a falling ceiling, a magic missile, etc. Targets who save versus spells are unaffected.
3. A scene: Either changing the appearance of the affected area or creating the appearance of something new. The scene disappears if touched.
Stipulations: The following apply:
‚ñ∂ Concentration: Is required to maintain the illusion. If the caster moves at faster than half speed or loses concentration, the spell ends.
‚ñ∂ Persistence: Even when the caster stops concentrating on the spell, the illusion persists for two further rounds.
‚ñ∂ Illusionary monsters or attacks: May appear to be harmful but never inflict real damage. A character who appears to die actually falls unconscious, a character turned to stone will actually be paralysed, and so on. Such effects last for 1d4 turns.
‚ñ∂ Illusions from imagination: If the illusion is of something the caster has not personally seen, the referee should grant targets a bonus to any applicable saving throws.

The caster or another creature or object within range becomes invisible:
‚ñ∂ If cast on a creature: Any gear the subject is carrying is also rendered invisible (this includes clothing and armour). Items dropped or put down by an invisible creature become visible. If the subject attacks or casts a spell, the invisibility is broken, ending the spell.
‚ñ∂ If cast on an object: The invisibility is permanent.
‚ñ∂ Light sources: If a light source is made invisible (either as part of a creature‚Äôs gear or as an individual object), the light it casts remains visible.

The caster imbues an inanimate object with a message that is to be spoken out loud by a magical mouth when a certain trigger condition occurs.
‚ñ∂ The message: Must be in a language the caster speaks and may consist of up to 25 words.
‚ñ∂ The trigger condition: May be as broad or as specific as the caster wishes. It may include conditions on the enchanted object being touched or on the presence of creatures within 30‚Äô of the object. The trigger condition may only take visual appearances into account (e.g. it cannot discern the alignment, class, level, etc. of creatures who pass by).
‚ñ∂ Once triggered: The mouth appears, animates, and speaks the predetermined message. The enchantment then ends.
‚ñ∂ Casting spells: The triggered message cannot cast spells.

1d4 illusory duplicates of the caster appear.
‚ñ∂ Behaviour: The mirror images look and behave exactly as the caster.
‚ñ∂ Attacks on the caster: Destroy one of the mirror images (even if the attack misses).

The caster‚Äôs physical form undergoes a quasi-real transformation, taking on the appearance of another creature.
‚ñ∂ The new form: Is chosen by the caster. The form of any creature may be adopted.
‚ñ∂ Size: The new form may be at most 50% larger or smaller than the caster‚Äôs normal size.
The physical capabilities of the new form: Are granted to the caster to a limited degree:
‚ñ∂ Flight: If the new form can fly, the caster is able to fly at one-quarter of its flying movement rate.
‚ñ∂ Breathing: If the new form can breathe underwater, the caster may also do so.
‚ñ∂ Attacks: When attacking, the caster may appear to use the attacks of the new form but cannot make more attack rolls or inflict more damage than they are normally able to (using whatever weapon is carried).
‚ñ∂ Special abilities: The caster does not gain any special or magical attacks possessed by the new form (e.g. breath weapons, poison, charm, etc.).

This spell allows the caster to send a message or other, non-verbal sound via the wind to a distant location within range.
‚ñ∂ The destination: Must be known to the caster.
‚ñ∂ The message: Up to 100 words or one minute of non-verbal sound.
‚ñ∂ Rate: The message travels on the wind, unnoticed, at one mile per turn.
‚ñ∂ Delivery: On reaching the designated destination, the wind delivers the caster‚Äôs message. The message is whisper quiet, relayed by the susurrations of the air, but can be heard by all within 30‚Äô. The message is delivered at the location whether or not anyone is present to hear it.

Twisting the nature of light and darkness, this spell creates a 30‚Äô diameter area of illumination which cannot be perceived outside of this area.
‚ñ∂ Stealth: It is thus possible for those within the area of blacklight to see in utter darkness while not revealing their own presence.
‚ñ∂ Area: The caster may cause the area of blacklight to manifest either in a designated area within range or about their own person. (In the latter case, the magical effect moves with the caster.)
‚ñ∂ Magical darkness: The illumination created by blacklight does not penetrate magical darkness.

Dispel illusion ends ongoing illusions or phantasms (i.e. those with a non-instantaneous duration) within a 20‚Äô cube area.
‚ñ∂ Spells cast by a non-illusionist: Are automatically dispelled.
‚ñ∂ Spells cast by another illusionist: Have a chance of not being dispelled. If the level of the caster of the effect to be dispelled is higher than the level of the caster of dispel illusion, there is a 5% chance per level difference that the attempt to dispel will fail.
‚ñ∂ Magic items: Are unaffected.

Conjures a cone of magical energy that terrifies those within it.
‚ñ∂ Effect: Creatures in the cone are struck with terror and will flee from the caster at maximum speed for one round per level of the caster. (A save versus spells negates the effect).
‚ñ∂ Dropping items: Affected creatures have a 60% chance of immediately dropping anything in their hands. The chance is decreased by 5% for each level or Hit Die above 1.

Hallucinatory terrain either conjures an illusory terrain feature (e.g. a hill, wood, marsh, etc.) or hides an existing terrain feature.
‚ñ∂ Area: The illusion must fit completely within the spell‚Äôs range.
‚ñ∂ Touching: If the illusion is touched by an intelligent being, the spell is negated.

A selected creature and all creatures within 10‚Äô of it become invisible:
‚ñ∂ Area: The 10‚Äô radius area of the spell‚Äôs effect moves with the chosen creature.
‚ñ∂ Exiting the area: Subjects that move more than 10‚Äô away from the chosen creature become visible.
‚ñ∂ Entering the area: Creatures that move into the area after the spell is cast do not become invisible.
‚ñ∂ Gear: Any gear a subject is carrying is also rendered invisible. Items dropped or put down by an invisible creature become visible. Carried light sources become invisible but the emitted light does not.
‚ñ∂ Breaking the invisibility: If a subject attacks or casts a spell, the invisibility is broken for that subject.
While this spell lasts, the caster is invisible to all forms of magical location, scrying, and divination, including effects such as clairvoyance, clairaudience, and ESP.

A number of creatures within a 20‚Äô cube area are afflicted with the terrifying phantasm of being unable to move.
‚ñ∂ Number of creatures affected: Up to 2HD of creatures per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Priority: Creatures with the lowest HD are affected first.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: Each target may save versus spells to resist the phantasm.
‚ñ∂ Mindless creatures: Are unaffected.
‚ñ∂ Cancelling: The caster may cancel the phantasm at will.

A quasi-real, shadowy, horse-like creature is conjured by this spell to carry the caster (or another, designated person) upon its back.
‚ñ∂ Appearance: The steed is deep black in colour and has ghostly hooves that make no sound as it runs.
‚ñ∂ Loads: The steed refuses to carry any load beyond that of the rider and their possessions.‚ñ∂ Stats: The steed has 12 hit points, AC 8 [11], and a movement rate of 30‚Äô (10‚Äô) per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ If the steed is killed: It evaporates into smoke.
Special abilities: The phantom steed gains additional abilities, depending on the level of the caster:
‚ñ∂ 8th level: The steed is unhindered by unstable ground (e.g. mud or bog).
‚ñ∂ 10th level: The steed may walk across water.
‚ñ∂ 12th level: The steed may walk upon air and is thus able to cross chasms and pits.
‚ñ∂ 14th level: The steed can fly.

A rope is enchanted to rise up into the air, enabling the caster and others to climb it and disappear into an imaginary space.
‚ñ∂ The rope: Rises up to its full length (or at most 30‚Äô) and hangs stiffly in the air, magically tethered at the upper end.
‚ñ∂ Climbing the rope: The rope may be climbed normally.
‚ñ∂ Imaginary space: Human-sized (or smaller) creatures that climb to the top of the rope disappear into the imaginary space beyond.
‚ñ∂ Capacity: The imaginary space can hold up to six individuals.
‚ñ∂ Hidden: Creatures inside the imaginary space cannot be perceived or affected in any way by those on the outside, in real space.
‚ñ∂ Pulling up the rope: The rope may be pulled up into the imaginary space, also disappearing.
When the spell‚Äôs duration ends: The rope falls slack, the imaginary space disappears, and anyone inside the imaginary space reappears in mid air.

An illusion of the caster‚Äôs choosing‚Äîincluding sounds, smells, and thermal elements‚Äîmanifests in a 20‚Äô cube area. Three types of illusions may be created:
1. An illusionary monster: That can be directed to attack. Refer to 'Illusionary Monster (Spectral Force)' stat block in the Monsters section for full details.
2. An illusionary attack: For example, an avalanche, a falling ceiling, a magic missile, etc. Targets who save versus spells are unaffected.
3. A scene: Either changing the appearance of the affected area or creating the appearance of something new. The scene disappears if touched.
Stipulations: The following apply:
‚ñ∂ Concentration: Is required to maintain the illusion. If the caster moves at faster than half speed or loses concentration, the spell ends.
‚ñ∂ Persistence: Even when the caster stops concentrating on the spell, the illusion persists for three further rounds.
‚ñ∂ Illusionary monsters or attacks: May appear to be harmful but never inflict real damage. A character who appears to die actually falls unconscious, a character turned to stone will actually be paralysed, and so on. Such effects last for 1d4 turns.
‚ñ∂ Illusions from imagination: If the illusion is of something the caster has not personally seen, the referee should grant targets a bonus to any applicable saving throws.

The caster utters a suggestion to influence the behaviour of a selected subject.
‚ñ∂ Wording: The suggestion must take the form of a short phrase (at most one or two sentences) suggesting a course of action to the subject.
‚ñ∂ Comprehension: A language that is understood by the subject must be used.
‚ñ∂ Harmful suggestions: Suggestions that are obviously harmful to the subject cause the spell to automatically fail.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: A save versus spells is allowed to resist the suggestion. If the save fails, the subject will follow the caster‚Äôs suggestion for up to the duration.
‚ñ∂ Reasonable suggestions: A suggestion that is worded in such a way to make it sound very reasonable incurs a ‚Äì2 penalty to the saving throw.
Restrictions: Undead are unaffected.

The caster‚Äôs person‚Äîalong with everything worn or carried‚Äîbecomes shadowy and semi-incorporeal.
‚ñ∂ Movement: The caster is able to pass through small holes and cracks.
‚ñ∂ Actions: The caster may cast spells but may only attack incorporeal creatures.
‚ñ∂ Invulnerability: Only magic and incorporeal creatures may harm the caster.
‚ñ∂ Pass undead: Undead will ignore the caster, believing them to be a phantom of some kind. Undead of 10 or more HD may save versus spells (at a ‚Äì4 penalty) to notice the illusion.
‚ñ∂ Cancelling: The caster may end the spell at will, returning to normal.

This spell causes 3d6 subjects within 60‚Äô of one another to become confused, making them unable to independently determine what they will do.
‚ñ∂ Subjects of 2+1 HD or greater: May save versus spells each round to resist the spell‚Äôs effect, acting with free will that round if they make the save.
‚ñ∂ Subjects of 2 HD or lower: May not make a saving throw.
‚ñ∂ Behaviour: Roll on the Confusion: Subject Behaviour table separately for each affected subject each round to determine how that subject acts that round:
Confusion: Subject Behaviour
2d6 Behaviour
2‚Äì5 Attack caster‚Äôs group
6‚Äì8 No action
9‚Äì12 Attack subject‚Äôs group

Dispel magic ends spells of non-instantaneous duration within a 20‚Äô cube area.
‚ñ∂ Caster levels: If the level of the caster of the effect to be dispelled is higher than the level of the caster of dispel magic, there is a 5% chance per level difference that the attempt to dispel will fail.
‚ñ∂ Magic items: Are unaffected.

All creatures in a 40‚Äô square area within range must save versus spells or be afflicted by an emotion of the caster‚Äôs choosing:
‚ñ∂ Fear: Subjects are struck with terror and will flee from the caster at maximum speed. Affected creatures have a 60% chance of immediately dropping anything in their hands. The chance is decreased by 5% for each level or Hit Die above 1. Fear counters ongoing rage effects.
‚ñ∂ Hate: Subjects gain a +2 bonus to attacks, damage, saving throws, and morale. Hate counters ongoing hopelessness effects.
‚ñ∂ Hopelessness: Subjects are utterly demoralised and will dejectedly follow enemies‚Äô orders (e.g. to surrender or leave). In combat, there is a 1-in-4 chance of a subject doing nothing each round, and a 1-in-4 chance of them retreating. Hopelessness counters ongoing hate effects.
‚ñ∂ Rage: Subjects go berserk, gaining a +1 bonus to hit and +3 to damage. Subjects fight without thought for their own lives and will not use shields. Subjects also gain 5 temporary hit points. These may take a subject above its normal maximum, but disappear when the spell ceases. Rage counters ongoing fear effects.
Concentration: Is required to maintain the projected emotion. If the caster moves or loses concentration, the spell ends.

Up to four persons touched by the caster are refreshed, some of their lost hit points being temporarily restored.
‚ñ∂ Bonus hit points: Each subject gains a number of bonus hit points equal to 50% of the number of hit points they are currently below maximum. For example, if the subject has a maximum of 30 hit points and a current total of 12 hit points, they gain 9 bonus hit points (50% of 18).
‚ñ∂ Any damage suffered: Is subtracted first from the bonus hit points.
‚ñ∂ When the duration ends: If any of the bonus hit points remain, they disappear.

Illusionist.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Illusionist.description:
The caster or another creature touched becomes invisible:
‚ñ∂ Attacking: The subject may attack while invisible.
‚ñ∂ Being attacked: Opponents who are aware of the subject‚Äôs presence (but who cannot see invisible) may detect a faint shimmering, allowing them to locate the subject. The subject gains a +4 bonus to AC and saving throws against attacks from such opponents.
‚ñ∂ Equipment: Any gear the subject is carrying is also rendered invisible (this includes clothing and armour). Items dropped or put down by an invisible creature become visible.
‚ñ∂ Light sources: If a light source is made invisible (as part of the subject‚Äôs gear), the light it casts is unaffected.

A force of human-sized creatures within a 240‚Äô diameter area is veiled by illusion to appear as a copse of trees or orchard.
‚ñ∂ Moving through: Once the illusion is in place, even creatures moving among the veiled subjects are deceived.
‚ñ∂ Subjects who leave the affected area: Cease to be veiled.
‚ñ∂ Dismissing: The caster may dismiss the illusion in its entirety at any time.

Over the course of one turn, the caster weaves a semi-real but tangible object from a tiny piece of constituent matter. For example, a semi-real rope could be formed from a strand of hemp fibre.
‚ñ∂ Non-living: Only objects of non-living vegetable matter may be created (e.g. fabric, rope, wood, etc.).
‚ñ∂ Size: The object may be no larger than one cubic foot per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Food: While it is possible to create food, its semi-real nature means that it provides no nourishment.
‚ñ∂ When the duration ends: The conjured item disappears. The piece of matter from which it was woven remains.

The subconscious fears of a single target manifest in its mind as a vision of the most horrible monstrosity it can imagine.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: The subject may save versus spells with a +2 bonus to resist the phantasm.
‚ñ∂ Pursuit: The monster pursues the subject relentlessly and, as it only exists in the subject‚Äôs mind, can move at any speed and pass through any obstacles.
‚ñ∂ Invulnerability: The monster is invulnerable to all of the subject‚Äôs attacks.
‚ñ∂ Attacks: The monster attacks the subject once per round with a THAC0 of 16 [+3]. If one of the monster‚Äôs attacks is successful, the subject dies of terror.
‚ñ∂ Cancelling: Killing or knocking out the caster ends the phantasm.
Restrictions: Undead and creatures of less than animal intelligence are unaffected.

A band of twisting, interweaving, rainbow colours fills the air in a 30‚Äô √ó 30‚Äô area centred on the caster.
‚ñ∂ Creatures that see the pattern: Must save versus spells or become hypnotised as long as they are able to watch the pattern.
‚ñ∂ Number of creatures affected: A total of up to 24 Hit Dice of creatures may be hypnotised.
‚ñ∂ Hypnotised creatures: Simply stand still, gazing at the pattern of colours.
‚ñ∂ If a hypnotised creature is harmed: The pattern ceases to enthral it and it may act next round.
Maintaining the pattern: The pattern can be maintained and directed as follows:
‚ñ∂ Concentration: The caster can maintain the pattern indefinitely, as long as they concentrate on the spell and remain stationary.
‚ñ∂ Releasing: The caster may optionally end concentration and direct the pattern to drift away in a specified direction. The pattern drifts at a rate of 30‚Äô per round and fades after 1d4 rounds. Hypnotised creatures will do their best to follow the pattern, but if they are led into a dangerous area, another saving throw versus spells is allowed to snap out of the trance.

The caster conjures one or more semi-real monsters, woven from shadow-stuff. Refer to 'Shadow Monster' stat block in the Monsters section for details on their properties based on successful or failed saving throws.
‚ñ∂ Hit Dice: The monsters‚Äô total Hit Dice may not exceed the caster‚Äôs level.
‚ñ∂ Type: All monsters must be of the same type.
‚ñ∂ Hit points: The monsters have 1d2 hit points per Hit Die (instead of the normal 1d8 hit points per Hit Die).
‚ñ∂ Control: The monsters are under the caster‚Äôs control.
Saving throw: Every creature viewing the shadow monsters may save versus spells:
‚ñ∂ If the save succeeds: The subject views the monsters as they truly are: vague, shifting forms of shadow. To this subject, the shadow monsters have AC 9 [10] and inflict one quarter of their normal damage (rounding down). This subject is unaffected by any special or magical attack forms of the monsters.
‚ñ∂ If the save fails: The subject perceives the monsters as real creatures of the chosen type. To this subject, the shadow monsters attack as normal and inflict normal damage. They may use any special or magical attack forms they possess, but attacks such as energy drain or petrification do not really occur‚Äîat worst, they might cause an opponent to fall unconscious or be paralysed for 1d4 turns.

A wall of roiling vapour appears at a location of the caster‚Äôs choosing within range.
‚ñ∂ Area: The fog bank fills a 10‚Äô cube area per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Vision: The solid fog blocks normal vision and infravision.
‚ñ∂ Movement: Creatures moving through the fog move at one tenth of their normal movement rate.
‚ñ∂ Strong winds: Only very strong winds can clear the fog before the spell‚Äôs duration has expired.
‚ñ∂ Magical fire: A large area of magical fire can dissipate the fog in one round.

An area is cloaked with a combination of invisibility and illusion, making it seem vacant and neglected‚Äîcovered in dust, cobwebs, and dirt, as if long abandoned.
‚ñ∂ Creatures: In the affected area when the spell is cast are not cloaked.
‚ñ∂ Inanimate objects: In the affected area are cloaked with invisibility and are veiled such that only direct contact will reveal their presence. Even then, an observer must make a saving throw versus spells to realise that the whole area is under the effects of an illusion: if the save fails, the observer believes that the detected object is merely invisible.
‚ñ∂ Creatures passing through the area: Believe that their passing makes footprints in the dust, breaks through cobwebs, etc.
‚ñ∂ Detection: Creatures that can detect invisible cannot see through this illusion.

This spell causes all creatures in a 60‚Äô diameter area to become confused, making them unable to independently determine what they will do.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: Subjects that can cast illusionist spells or that have innate powers of illusion may save versus spells to resist the spell‚Äôs effect.
‚ñ∂ Behaviour: Roll on the following table separately for each affected subject each round to determine how that subject acts that round:
Chaos: Subject Behaviour
2d6 Behaviour
2‚Äì5 Attack caster‚Äôs group
6‚Äì8 No action
9‚Äì12 Attack subject‚Äôs group

The caster conjures one or more semi-real monsters, woven from shadow-stuff.
‚ñ∂ Hit Dice: The monsters‚Äô total Hit Dice may not exceed the caster‚Äôs level.
‚ñ∂ Type: All monsters must be of the same type.
‚ñ∂ Hit points: The monsters have 1d4 hit points per Hit Die (instead of the normal 1d8 hit points per Hit Die).
‚ñ∂ Control: The monsters are under the caster‚Äôs control.
Saving throw: Every creature viewing the shadow monsters may save versus spells:
‚ñ∂ If the save succeeds: The subject views the monsters as they truly are: vague, shifting forms of shadow. To this subject, the shadow monsters have AC 9 [10] and inflict half of their normal damage (rounding down). This subject is unaffected by any special or magical attack forms of the monsters.
‚ñ∂ If the save fails: The subject perceives the monsters as real creatures of the chosen type. To this subject, the shadow monsters attack as normal and inflict normal damage. They may use any special or magical attack forms they possess, but attacks such as energy drain or petrification do not really occur‚Äîat worst, they might cause an opponent to fall unconscious or be paralysed for 1d4 turns.
Refer to appropriate monster stat blocks for chosen type.

An illusion of the caster‚Äôs choosing‚Äîincluding sounds, smells, and thermal elements‚Äîmanifests in a 20‚Äô cube area. Three types of illusions may be created:
1. An illusionary monster: That can be directed to attack. The monster has AC 5 [14]. If it is hit in combat, the attacker may save versus spells. If the save succeeds, the attacker realises the illusory nature of the monster and can no longer be harmed by it.
2. An illusionary attack: For example, an avalanche, a falling ceiling, a magic missile, etc. Targets who save versus spells are unaffected.
3. A scene: Either changing the appearance of the affected area or creating the appearance of something new.
Stipulations: The following apply:
‚ñ∂ Responsiveness: The illusion behaves and responds as decided by the caster when the spell is cast. No concentration is required to maintain the illusion.
‚ñ∂ Illusionary monsters or attacks: May appear to be harmful but never inflict real damage. A character who appears to die actually falls unconscious, a character turned to stone will actually be paralysed, and so on. Such effects last for 1d4 turns.
‚ñ∂ Illusions from imagination: If the illusion is of something the caster has not personally seen, the referee should grant targets a bonus to any applicable saving throws.

A finely wrought, silver mirror is enchanted to act as a scrying device, allowing the caster to fleetingly view any place or object that is brought to mind:
‚ñ∂ The clarity of the vision: Depends on the scryer‚Äôs familiarity with the subject.
‚ñ∂ Casting spells: It is not possible to cast spells through the mirror into the viewed scene.
Material cost: The mirror enchanted by this spell must be of at least 1,000gp value.

Over the course of a turn, the caster weaves a semi-real but tangible object from a tiny piece of constituent matter. For example, a sword could be formed from a splinter of steel.
‚ñ∂ Non-living: Only objects of non-living vegetable or mineral matter may be created (e.g. fabric, rope, wood, metal, stone, etc.).
‚ñ∂ Size: The object may be no larger than one cubic foot per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Food: While it is possible to create food, its semi-real nature means that it provides no nourishment.
‚ñ∂ duration: If objects of vegetable matter are created, the duration is 12 turns per level, otherwise it is 6 turns per level.
‚ñ∂ When the duration ends: The conjured item disappears. The piece of matter from which it was woven remains.

A single subject within range is transported into a shifting, extra-dimensional mirror maze.
‚ñ∂ duration: The subject is trapped in the maze for a duration depending on its intelligence. See the table below.
‚ñ∂ Escaping the maze: Once the subject has found its way out of the maze, it reappears in the location it was transported from.
Maze of Mirrors duration
Subject‚Äôs INT duration
Less than 3 2d4 turns
3‚Äì5 1d4 turns
6‚Äì8 5d4 rounds
9‚Äì11 4d4 rounds
12‚Äì14 3d4 rounds
15‚Äì17 2d4 rounds
18 or higher 1d4 rounds

An illusory duplicate of the caster appears within range.
‚ñ∂ Duplicate: The image is an exact duplicate of the caster that can only be differentiated by touch.
‚ñ∂ Subsequent spells cast: Appear to originate from the image. (Targets must still be visible to the caster, however.)
‚ñ∂ Spells and missiles: The image appears unaffected by spells or missile weapons.
‚ñ∂ Melee or touch: If the image is touched or hit in melee, it disappears.

This spell alters the outward appearance of one or more persons to that of another type of humanoid.
‚ñ∂ Number of subjects: Up to one subject per two levels of the caster may be affected.
‚ñ∂ The illusionary appearance: All subjects take on the appearance of the same type of creature (e.g. human, elf, goblin, etc.), but each remains a recognisable individual‚Äîthey do not look like clones.
‚ñ∂ Size and weight: The illusionary appearance may be at most 1‚Äô taller or shorter than the subject. Apparent weight may be altered in any way.
‚ñ∂ Clothing or equipment: May be altered in any way.
‚ñ∂ Cloning: The spell cannot be used to precisely copy another‚Äôs appearance.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: Unwilling subjects may save versus spells to avoid being affected.

The shadows cast by the light of a candle are enchanted, causing them to re-enact events which previously occurred in the area where the spell is cast.
‚ñ∂ Candle: The caster must light a candle and place it in the centre of the area to be affected, which must otherwise be in darkness. The candle burns down completely over the spell‚Äôs duration.
‚ñ∂ Time span: The caster may choose to look back into the past up to six turns plus one turn per level.
‚ñ∂ Shadow play: Once the starting point for the shadow re-enactment has been selected, the spell lasts for that amount of time, producing a shadowy replay of the past up to the moment the spell was cast.
‚ñ∂ Silhouettes: Only silhouettes of past events in the area are produced; any sound or speech which occurred is not replicated.
Enhancement: The power of the illusion may be enhanced by using a specially manufactured candle:
‚ñ∂ Special candle: The candle must be formed from the earwax of a giant monster (which must be obtained by adventuring) and be inlaid with fine runes in gold leaf (at a cost of 200gp).
‚ñ∂ Sound: If such a candle is used, the shadow play is also accompanied by sound, faintly reproduced in the sputtering of the candle‚Äôs flame.

Illusionist.spell_range: The caster or an object or creature touched
Illusionist.description:
An object or creature touched becomes shadowy and semi-ethereal.
If an object is touched:
‚ñ∂ Insubstantial: The object becomes utterly insubstantial. It cannot be touched and provides no physical resistance. For example, a door transformed by this spell could be freely passed through.
‚ñ∂ Size: The object may be no larger than one cubic foot per level of the caster.
‚ñ∂ Magical objects: Magic items and objects created by spells (e.g. a wall of stone) cannot be targeted.
If a creature is touched:
‚ñ∂ Insubstantial: The subject and everything it carries becomes insubstantial.
‚ñ∂ Movement: The subject is able to pass through small holes and cracks.
‚ñ∂ Invulnerability: Only ethereal creatures or magic may harm the subject.
‚ñ∂ Pass undead: Undead will ignore the subject, believing them to be a phantom of some kind. Undead of 10 or more HD may save versus spells (at a ‚Äì4 penalty) to notice the illusion.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: An unwilling subject may save versus spells to avoid the transformation.

Necromancer.description:
The caster‚Äôs hands are enveloped with a chilling, blue miasma that disrupts the life energy of any living creature touched.
Attack roll: In combat, a melee attack roll is required.
Effects: The victim suffers 1d4 damage and loses 1 point of STR. If the victim does not have a rated STR score, they instead suffer a ‚Äì1 penalty to attack rolls each time they are touched.
Recovering: Lost points of Strength are recovered at a rate of one per hour.

2d6 humanoid corpses or skeletons within range rise up as undead and obey the caster‚Äôs commands for a short time.
Combat stats: Each reanimated corpse or skeleton has 1 hit point and attacks using the stats listed under 'Commanded Dead' in the Monsters section.
Special abilities: They are unable to use any special abilities (including spell casting) that they possessed in life.

The caster‚Äôs face and voice replicate those of a corpse touched.
Limitations: The spell only works on the corpse of a humanoid deceased within the last week.
Decay: The caster‚Äôs face and voice reflect the exact state of the target corpse. If the corpse is decayed, the caster‚Äôs face will appear rotting and their voice ragged and rasping.

This spell has two usages (chosen when cast):
1. Destroy tissue: A touched corpse or dead body part (e.g. dismembered limb, extracted organ, etc.) is eaten away to bones in 1 turn, devoured by a gruesomely accelerated mass of maggots and mould. For the purposes of raise dead, a decayed corpse is treated as being 6 days old + 1 day per level of the caster.
2. Harm undead: Decay inflicts 2d6 damage against an undead monster with flesh (e.g. zombie, ghoul). The target must be touched in the round the spell is cast, requiring a successful melee attack.
Reversed: Ward Against Decay
A single corpse or dead body part (e.g. dismembered limb, extracted organ, etc.) is permanently protected from the natural processes of decay and deterioration.

A single corpse or dead body part (e.g. dismembered limb, extracted organ, etc.) is permanently protected from the natural processes of decay and deterioration.
Reversed: Decay
This spell has two usages (chosen when cast):
1. Destroy tissue: A touched corpse or dead body part (e.g. dismembered limb, extracted organ, etc.) is eaten away to bones in 1 turn, devoured by a gruesomely accelerated mass of maggots and mould. For the purposes of raise dead, a decayed corpse is treated as being 6 days old + 1 day per level of the caster.
2. Harm undead: Decay inflicts 2d6 damage against an undead monster with flesh (e.g. zombie, ghoul). The target must be touched in the round the spell is cast, requiring a successful melee attack.

A single skull, skeleton, corpse, or undead monster is wreathed with flickering light.
Light: 15‚Ä≤ radius. May be of any colour the caster chooses.
Saving throw: An intelligent undead monster may save versus spells to resist.
Counters invisibility: The flickering light makes it impossible for the target to become fully invisible.

This spell enables the caster to divine the presence of undead creatures within range.
Information: The spell indicates neither the precise location nor the type of any undead detected, only their direction.
Obstruction: The ability to detect undead is blocked by 1‚Ä≤ of stone, 3‚Ä≤ of earth, or a thin layer of metal.

Necromancer.spell_duration: Concentration, up to 1 round per level
Necromancer.description:
The caster takes control of a single creature, moving it around as they wish, like a puppet.
Targets: The spell can target either a corporeal undead monster of up to 4 HD or a human, demihuman, or human-like monster (see Persons under Monsters, in Old-School Essentials).
Saving throw: The victim may save versus paralysis to resist the spell.
Actions: The caster can make the victim move, attack, freeze, or act in any way desired. Control is imperfect, however: the victim moves jerkily and acts without precision, making attack rolls at a ‚Äì2 penalty.
Special abilities: The caster cannot command the victim to use any special abilities they possess (e.g. poison, breath weapons, spells, etc.).
Self-destructive acts: Acts that are self-destructive or against the victim‚Äôs habits or alignment allow another save to break the magical control.
Concentration: Being distracted (e.g. attacked) or performing any other action (except moving) causes the spell to end.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
The subject is rendered completely undetectable to undead.
Detection: Undead with 6 or more HD may save versus spells to detect anyone protected by this spell. Undead with 9 or more HD are never deceived by the spell.
Hostile actions: Taking hostile action against undead (e.g. attacking, casting offensive spells) reveals the subject‚Äôs presence, but only to the affected individuals.

This spell wards the caster from attacks by creatures of another alignment, as follows:
Bonuses: The caster gains a +1 bonus to saving throws against attacks or special abilities of affected creatures.
Affected creatures‚Äô attacks: Against the caster are penalised by ‚Äì1.
Enchanted, constructed, or summoned creatures: The spell additionally prevents such creatures from attacking the caster in melee, though they may still make ranged attacks. If the caster engages such a creature in melee, this protection is broken (the caster still gains the save and attack bonuses mentioned above).

Allows the caster to decipher magical script or runes, as follows:
Scrolls: The magical script of a scroll of arcane spells can be understood. The caster is then able to activate the scroll at any time in the future.
Spell books: A spell book written by another arcane spell caster can be deciphered.
Inscriptions: Runes or magical words inscribed on an object or surface can be understood.
Reading again: Once the caster has used this spell to decipher a magical inscription, they can always understand that script again without read magic.

The caster may cause a single skull within range to speak in a rasping whisper.
Words: The caster may cause the skull to utter any words desired. It is not possible to cast spells via the skull.
Undead monsters: An undead monster‚Äôs skull may be caused to speak. Intelligent undead may save versus paralysis to resist.

This spell temporarily reanimates the bones or body of a single dead humanoid into an undead skeleton or zombie.
Obedient: The undead servitor obeys the caster‚Äôs commands.
Special abilities: The servitor is unable to use any special abilities (including spell casting) that it possessed in life.
Refer to 'Skeleton Servitor' or 'Zombie Servitor' stat blocks in the Monsters section for full details, depending on the type of servitor created.

Plates of jagged bone surround the caster, acting as a formidable suit of armour. Armour Class: The bone armour grants AC 5 [14]. In melee: Any creature that successfully attacks the caster in melee suffers 1d3 damage, due to flying fragments of jagged bone. Destruction: The armour lasts until the caster suffers 5 points of damage, +1 point per level.

A pair of spectral hands clasp around the throat of a living creature and begin choking them.
Saving throw: The victim may save versus spells to negate the spell.
Damage: The victim automatically suffers 1d4 damage per round.
Attack penalty: The victim suffers a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls.
Escaping: Due to their ghostly nature, the choking hands cannot be wrenched away from the victim. However, the spell is negated if the caster is killed or knocked unconscious.

Upon casting this spell and touching the body of a creature which has died within the last 24 hours, the caster experiences a vision of the last 10 minutes of the creature‚Äôs life, ending with its demise.
Trance: While witnessing the deceased creature‚Äôs last moments of life, the caster is in a trance state, unable to move or perceive their surroundings.
Enchanted objects, areas, or creatures are caused to glow. Both permanent and temporary enchantments are revealed.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
A willing subject falls into a cataleptic state, indistinguishable from death.
Hit Dice limit: The subject may not have higher HD than the caster‚Äôs level.
Senses: The subject retains their senses of hearing and smell, but cannot see or feel.
Damage: Any damage inflicted on the subject is halved.
Immunities: The subject is unaffected by paralysis and energy drain.
Poison: The effects of any poison in the subject‚Äôs system are suspended while the spell lasts. Once the duration ends, poison has its normal effect once more.
Ending: The caster can end the spell at any time. The subject requires 1 round to awaken.

The caster‚Äôs touch paralyses living creatures.
Attack roll: In combat, a melee attack roll is required.
Effects: The victim must save versus paralysis or be paralysed (magically frozen; unable to move or speak) for 2d4 turns.
Restrictions: Elves and creatures larger than ogres are unaffected.

A magical seal is placed on a single crypt door or coffer lid, causing it to close and become magically locked.
Bypassing: The magical seal is permanent but may be bypassed as follows:
‚ñ∂ The caster: Can freely pass their own seal.
‚ñ∂ A knock spell: Allows passage.
‚ñ∂ Higher level casters: Magic-using characters 3 or more levels higher than the caster of seal tomb may pass.
Temporary: Bypassing does not end a seal tomb spell.
Reversed: Open Tomb
Causes a crypt door or coffer lid to open. Magical locks: Spells such as seal tomb and wizard lock are dispelled.
Wards: Warding spells normally triggered by opening the door are temporarily bypassed.

Causes a crypt door or coffer lid to open.
Magical locks: Spells such as seal tomb and wizard lock are dispelled.
Wards: Warding spells normally triggered by opening the door are temporarily bypassed.
Reversed: Seal Tomb
A magical seal is placed on a single crypt door or coffer lid, causing it to close and become magically locked.
Bypassing: The magical seal is permanent but may be bypassed as follows:
‚ñ∂ The caster: Can freely pass their own seal.
‚ñ∂ A knock spell: Allows passage.
‚ñ∂ Higher level casters: Magic-using characters 3 or more levels higher than the caster of seal tomb may pass.
Temporary: Bypassing does not end a seal tomb spell.

Conjures a skeletal horse that will carry the caster (or another designated person) upon its back.
Move silently: The steed moves with a preternatural silence.
Loads: The steed can carry one rider and up to 3,000 coins of weight. Any weight beyond this causes the spell to end.
Expiration: When the duration expires, the skeletal horse crumbles into dust.
Refer to 'Skeletal Horse' stat block in the Monsters section for full details.

Binding their eyes with a cloth, the caster gains the ability to see through the empty eye sockets of a humanoid skull, often one worn as a necklace or placed atop a staff.
Dark vision: The skull can see normally, up to 60‚Ä≤, in absolute darkness.
Distance: If the caster moves more than 30‚Ä≤ away from the skull, the spell ends.
Removing the cloth: If the caster removes the cloth covering their eyes, the spell ends.

A 15‚Ä≤ radius area is rendered utterly silent.
Within the area: All sound is prevented.
Conversation and spell casting are impossible.
Noise from outside the area: Can be heard by those within it.
Casting upon a creature: Silence may be cast upon a creature, which must save versus spells. If the save fails, the 15‚Ä≤ radius area of silence moves with the creature. If the save succeeds, the spell‚Äôs effect remains stationary‚Äîthe targeted creature may move out of it.

The caster may ask questions of a deceased person, the spirit‚Äôs voice echoing out from beyond the grave.
Remains: Some remnant of the person‚Äôs physical body (e.g. bones) must be within range.
Time since death: It is only possible to awaken the spirit of a person who died within a certain time frame, dependent on the caster‚Äôs level (see table below).
Questions: The number which can be asked depends on the caster‚Äôs level (see table below). The spirit answers truthfully but briefly, and only possesses knowledge it had during life.
Speech: The spirit speaks with the tongues it knew in life.
Speak With Dead Limitations
Level 6 or lower: 7 days, 2 Questions
Level 7‚Äì8: 7 months, 3 Questions
Level 9‚Äì10: 7 years, 4 Questions
Level 11‚Äì12: 70 years, 5 Questions
Level 13+: Unlimited, 6 Questions

A glowing, ghostly hand formed of the caster‚Äôs own life force manifests at their side.
Moving the hand: By concentrating, the caster can direct the hand to move, within range. The hand can move up to 60‚Ä≤ per round.
Touch attacks: The hand can be used to deliver spells of up to 4th level that take effect via touch. When making a touch attack with the hand, the caster gains a +2 bonus to attack rolls.
Concentration: Moving, attacking, or performing any other action besides casting spells causes the hand to return to hover at the caster‚Äôs side.
Vulnerability: As the hand is formed of the caster‚Äôs life force, it is vulnerable to attack. It can only be harmed by magic and magic weapons, and has AC ‚Äì2 [21]. If the hand is damaged, the spell ends and the caster suffers 1d4 damage.

May be used in one of two situations:
1. Battle: Allies within a 20‚Äô square area who are not yet in melee gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls and a +1 bonus to morale.
2. Ritual: Casting bless may also form part of rituals of purification or consecration, at the referee‚Äôs discretion.
Reversed: Blight
Incurs a ‚Äì1 penalty to morale checks, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies within a 20‚Äô square area. A save versus spells is allowed to resist the blight.

Incurs a ‚Äì1 penalty to morale checks, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies within a 20‚Äô square area. A save versus spells is allowed to resist the blight.
Reversed: Bless
May be used in one of two situations:
1. Battle: Allies within a 20‚Äô square area who are not yet in melee gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls and a +1 bonus to morale.
2. Ritual: Casting bless may also form part of rituals of purification or consecration, at the referee‚Äôs discretion.

Causes corpses or skeletons to rise as undead skeletons or zombies.
Obedient: Created undead obey the caster‚Äôs commands.
Special abilities: They are unable to use any special abilities (including spell casting) that they possessed in life.
Expiration: When the duration expires, the animated dead crumble into dust.
Number: The spell animates up to 1 Hit Die of zombies or skeletons per level of the caster.
Refer to 'Animated Skeleton' and 'Animated Zombie' stat blocks in the Monsters section for full details.

A normal bone in the caster‚Äôs hand is transformed into a magic staff that the caster or another may wield in combat.
Length: Whatever its original size, the enchanted bone grows to 6‚Ä≤ in length.
In melee: The staff is treated as a +1 weapon, granting a +1 bonus to attack rolls and inflicting 1d6+1 damage.
Expiration: When the duration ends, the staff shatters into dust.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
The subject exudes a nauseating carrion stench, detectable up to 60‚Ä≤ away.
Close range: All living creatures within 10‚Ä≤ of the subject (including allies, but excluding the caster and subject) must save versus poison or suffer a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls due to nausea.
Duration: Affected creatures suffer the nausea effect for 1 turn after leaving the subject‚Äôs presence.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
The subject is able to see normally up to 30‚Ä≤ in utter blackness.
Acuity: Unlike infravision, the sight granted by this spell allows the subject to perceive fine detail, including script.

A living subject is warded such that they do not die when reduced to 0 hit points, instead being able to survive and continue to act normally until they reach ‚Äì10 hit points.
Death saves: The subject also gains a +2 bonus to saving throws versus death or poison.
Healing: Healing magic functions normally for a character under this ward. For example, a character could be reduced to ‚Äì8hp, then receive a healing spell taking them up to ‚Äì2hp, then drink a potion of healing taking them up to 3hp.
Expiration: Once the spell expires, if the subject has 0 or less hit points, they die immediately.

A subject killed by damage (i.e. not by poison, disintegration, etc.) within the last 3 rounds is dragged back from the brink of death.
Weakness: Returning from death is an ordeal. Until the subject gets two full weeks of bed rest, they have 1 hit point, move at half the normal rate, cannot carry heavy items, and cannot attack, cast spells, or use other class abilities. This period of weakness may not be shortened by any magical healing.
Bargain: In return for cheating death, the necromancer suffers 1d6 damage and the subject suffers a permanent loss of one point from a random ability score.

Conjures a cone of magical energy that terrifies those within it.
Effect: Creatures in the cone are struck with terror and will flee from the caster at maximum speed for one round per level of the caster. (A save versus spells negates the effect).
Dropping items: Affected creatures have a 60% chance of immediately dropping anything in their hands. The chance is decreased by 5% for each level or Hit Die above 1.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
The subject can survive without air for the duration. Their natural breathing wheezes and comes to a stop.
Immunities: The subject is immune to drowning and to poison gases.
Choking: Damage from choking (e.g. the choke spell) is reduced by half.

This spell causes one or more humans, demihumans, or human-like monsters (see Persons under Monsters, in Old-School Essentials) to be paralysed (magically frozen; unable to move or speak) if they fail a saving throw versus spells. It may be cast in two ways:
1. Against an individual: The target‚Äôs saving throw is penalised by ‚Äì2.
2. Against a group: 1d4 individuals in the group are targeted.
Restrictions: Undead and human-like monsters of greater than 4+1 HD (see Hit point modifiers under Monsters, in Old-School Essentials) are not affected.

This spell wards the caster and all allies within 10‚Ä≤ from attacks by creatures of another alignment, as follows:
Bonuses: Those warded gain a +1 bonus to saving throws against attacks or special abilities of affected creatures.
Affected creatures‚Äô attacks: Against those warded are penalised by ‚Äì1.
Enchanted, constructed, or summoned creatures: The spell additionally prevents such creatures from making melee attacks against those warded, though they may still make ranged attacks. If any of the warded party engages such a creature in melee, this protection is broken (those warded still gain the save and attack bonuses mentioned above).

A humanoid skull is enchanted to explode on contact.
Contact: The explosion is triggered if the skull is touched by a living creature or is otherwise forcefully contacted. Treat as AC 7 [12] for purposes of firing missiles to hit the skull.
Explosion: A 10‚Ä≤ radius blast of violet flame and necrotic energy.
Damage: Creatures caught in the blast suffer 1d4 damage per level of the caster, with a successful save versus spells indicating half damage.

The caster‚Äôs touch drains hit points from a living creature, healing the caster by a like amount.
Attack roll: In combat, a melee attack roll is required. If the attack is unsuccessful, the spell is not used up.
Damage: The victim suffers 1d6 damage per 2 levels of the caster, to a maximum of 6d6 damage.
Healing: The caster gains hit points equal to the damage inflicted. Any excess hit points above the caster‚Äôs maximum are treated as bonus hit points.
Bonus hit points: Damage suffered is subtracted first from any bonus hit points. Bonus hit points disappear after 1 hour.

Necromancer.spell_duration: Depends on intelligence of the target
Necromancer.description:
This spell brings one or more undead monsters under the caster‚Äôs control. The effects differ depending on the intelligence of the monsters targeted.

Mindless undead:
‚ñ∂ Targets: Multiple mindless undead monsters (e.g. skeletons, zombies) totalling up to 1 HD per level of the caster can be affected.
‚ñ∂ Obedient: The monsters mindlessly obey the caster‚Äôs commands.
‚ñ∂ duration: Permanent.

Intelligent undead:
‚ñ∂ Targets: A single monster of Hit Dice not exceeding the caster‚Äôs level can be affected.
‚ñ∂ Saving throw: The monster may save versus spells to negate the spell.
‚ñ∂ Mastery: The monster regards the caster as its master and will come to the caster‚Äôs defence.
‚ñ∂ Commands: If they share a language, the caster may give the monster commands, which it will obey.
‚ñ∂ Suicidal commands: The affected monster never obeys suicidal or obviously harmful orders.
‚ñ∂ duration: The control lasts indefinitely, but the monster may save versus spells once per month to break free. Monsters of greater than 3 HD may save once per week, and monsters of greater than 6 HD may save once per day.

The caster can see and hear through the dead eyes and ears of a corpse.
Range: The caster may move up to a mile away from the corpse and still receive its sensory impressions.
Undead: Animated corpses (e.g. zombies) may be affected, and an affected corpse may subsequently be animated. Intelligent undead may save versus spells to resist the communion.

The face of a humanoid corpse twists into a replica of another person‚Äôs face.
Mental image: The caster must have a clear mental image of the person to be replicated (e.g. a portrait, personal meeting).
Replica: The replicated face is a perfect duplicate. The corpse‚Äôs body is unchanged by this spell.
Undead: Animated corpses (e.g. zombies) may be affected, and an affected corpse may subsequently be animated.

Places a deleterious effect upon a creature, if it fails a save versus spells.
Effects: The exact form and effects of the curse are determined by the caster.
Maximum possible effects include: A ‚Äì2 saving throw penalty, a ‚Äì4 attack roll penalty, reducing an ability score by 50%.
Multiple curses: May afflict a creature, as long as each has a different effect.
Referee judgement: The referee should judge the effects of this spell and may turn overly powerful curses back onto the caster!

Dispel magic ends spell effects within a 20‚Ä≤ cube.
Caster levels: Effects created by lower level casters are automatically dispelled.
Effects created by higher level casters have a 5% chance per level difference of not being dispelled.
Magic items: Are unaffected.

A sinister force drags a single target into the earth over the course of 2d4 rounds.
Hit Dice limit: The target‚Äôs Hit Dice may not exceed the caster‚Äôs level.
Saving throw: A save versus death is allowed to resist the spell.
Aid: A creature of giant strength or multiple creatures with a combined STR score of 50 or more can prevent the victim‚Äôs interment.
Effect: If the victim fails to resist, they are interred 10‚Ä≤ beneath the earth. Suffocation usually occurs within 1d4 rounds.

Causes buried bodies within range to rise to the surface of the earth.
Depth: Corpses buried deeper than 20‚Ä≤ cannot be exhumed.
Selecting: The caster may optionally choose which bodies are exhumed (for example, by reading names from gravestones).

The caster‚Äôs touch inflicts a horrible rotting disease on living creatures.
Attack roll: In combat, a melee attack roll is required.
Effects: The victim receives no benefit from magical healing. Natural healing is ten times slower.
Removing: The disease can only be removed by magic (e.g. cure disease).

This spell repairs corporeal undead monsters, stitching rended flesh and knitting shattered bone back together. It has two usages:
1. Restore hit points: A total of 1d4 hit points per level of the caster can be repaired, divided between any number of corporeal undead within range.
2. Reanimate: Corporeal undead monsters killed within the last turn are restored to 1d4 hit points and reanimated. Up to 1 HD of monsters per level of the caster are affected.

Conjures a skeletal horse with ragged, bat-like wings that will carry the caster (or another designated person) upon its back.
Move silently: The steed moves with a preternatural silence.
Loads: The steed can carry one rider and up to 3,000 coins of weight. Any weight beyond this causes the spell to end.
Expiration: When the duration expires, the skeletal horse crumbles into dust.

The caster, their clothing, and all carried items transform into a scurrying swarm of rats, spiders, or insects.
Movement: While in swarm form, the caster can move at 60‚Ä≤ (20‚Ä≤).
Attacks: The swarm can attack by engulfing victims within a 10‚Ä≤ √ó 10‚Ä≤ area. Victims suffer damage (no attack roll): 2hp if wearing armour, 4hp without. Victims who defend themselves by brandishing a weapon (or similar) suffer half damage from the swarm.
Immunity: The swarm is immune to normal damage, but can be harmed by fire, spells, or area attacks (e.g. breath attacks).
Duration: The caster can end the spell‚Äôs effect at any time, returning to their normal physical form. If the caster is killed, they also return to their normal form.

An immobile wall of jagged bones springs into existence.
Size: The wall can be any length, height, and shape the caster wishes, up to 1,200 sq. ft total. For example, it may be a straight wall 10‚Ä≤ high and 120‚Ä≤ long or a ring 20‚Ä≤ high and 10‚Ä≤ radius.
Location: The wall must be supported (e.g. by the ground) and cannot be created in an area occupied by objects.
Cover: Missiles may be fired through gaps in the bone wall, suffering a ‚Äì3 penalty to attack rolls.
Monsters with fewer than 4 HD: Cannot pass the wall of bones.
Monsters with 4 or more HD: Can break through the wall, but suffer 1d8 hit points of damage when doing so.

The subject‚Äôs wounds are transferred to the caster.
Healing: The subject is healed of up to 2hp per level of the caster (at most as many hit points as the caster currently has). The caster may decide how many hit points to heal.
Wounding: The caster suffers damage equal to the hit points healed.

Causes corpses or skeletons to rise as undead skeletons or zombies.
Obedient: Created undead obey the caster‚Äôs commands.
Special abilities: They are unable to use any special abilities (including spell casting) that they possessed in life.
Duration: The reanimating magic remains active until dispelled or until the undead are slain.
Number: The spell animates up to 1 Hit Die of zombies or skeletons per level of the caster:
‚ñ∂ Skeletons: Have AC 7 [12] and HD equal to those the creature had in life.
‚ñ∂ Zombies: Have AC 8 [11] and HD one greater than the creature had in life.
Classed characters: If a PC or NPC with levels in a class is reanimated by this spell, the levels are not counted as HD. For example, the reanimated corpse of a 5th level fighter would have 2 HD (1 HD as a normal human, +1 for being reanimated as a zombie).

The bones of the targeted living creature agonisingly warp and throb inside its flesh.
Saving throw: The victim may save versus spells to negate the spell.
Damage: The victim automatically suffers 1d6 damage per round.
Penalties: The victim suffers a ‚Äì2 penalty to Armour Class and attack rolls. The victim‚Äôs movement rate is halved.

A poisonous fog streams from the caster‚Äôs fingertips, filling a 30‚Ä≤ diameter area.
Movement: The fog moves at 60‚Ä≤ (20‚Ä≤), driven by the wind or, in still conditions, away from the caster.
Sinking: Because the fog is denser than air, it sinks to the lowest point, flowing down hills, into holes, and so forth.
Damage: All creatures in contact with the fog suffer 1 damage per round.
Creatures with less than 5 Hit Dice: Must also save versus death (once per round of contact) or die.

Necromancer.spell_range: Spirit manifests in the caster‚Äôs presence
Necromancer.description:
The caster calls upon the spirit of a deceased person, seeking knowledge they possessed during life.
Chance of success: The chance that the spirit will respond to the spell is mostly dependent on how long it has been deceased (see table below).
Modifiers: The time at which the spell is cast also affects success: daytime ‚Äì25%, full moon +10%, festival of the dead +25%. Regardless of modifiers, the maximum chance of success is 95% and the minimum 5%.
Failure: On a roll of 96‚Äì00, malicious undead spirits (1d6 spectres) are summoned.
Success: If the spirit is successfully summoned, it rises before the caster as a shade visible to all present.
Questions: The caster may ask up to one question per experience level above 8th.
Reaction: To determine the spirit‚Äôs attitude, the referee should roll 2d6, applying the caster‚Äôs NPC reactions modifier due to CHA (see Ability Scores in Old-School Essentials). If the spirit is a different alignment than the caster, a ‚Äì2 penalty applies.
Knowledge: The spirit only possesses knowledge it had during life.
Speech: The spirit magically speaks the same language as the caster.

Commune With Spirit Base Chance
Time Since Death Base Chance
1 week 60% + caster‚Äôs level
1 month 55% + caster‚Äôs level
1 year 50% + caster‚Äôs level
10 years 45% + caster‚Äôs level
100 years 40% + caster‚Äôs level
1,000 years 30% + caster‚Äôs level
Unlimited 10% + caster‚Äôs level

Commune With Spirit Reaction
2d6 Reaction
2 or less Resentful. Brief, untruthful answers.
3‚Äì5 Reluctant. Brief, cryptic answers.
6‚Äì8 Amenable. Brief, truthful answers.
9‚Äì11 Eager. Detailed, truthful answers.
12 or more Impassioned. Fully elaborated, truthful answers.

The caster, their clothing, and all carried items transform into a cloud of mist.
Movement: The caster moves at 60‚Ä≤ (20‚Ä≤) and is able to pass through small holes and cracks.
Actions: The caster cannot attack, speak, or cast spells.
Invulnerability: The caster can only be harmed by magic and magic weapons.
Duration: The caster can end the spell‚Äôs effect at any time, returning to their normal physical form. If the caster is killed, they also return to their normal form.

Necromancer.spell_duration: 1 day per level or until manifested
Necromancer.description:
The caster summons a lost soul from the realms of the dead and tasks it to guard the location where this spell is cast.
Warding: Once summoned, the spirit lies dormant and invisible in the locale to be protected, but will manifest when a trigger condition is satisfied.
The trigger condition: May be as broad or as specific as the caster wishes. It may include conditions on creatures entering the warded area or touching anything within. The trigger condition may only take visual appearances into account (e.g. it cannot discern the alignment, class, level, etc. of creatures who enter).
Once triggered: The guardian spirit manifests in a form selected by the caster when the spell was cast (see possible manifestations, below).
Following manifestation: The spirit is released from its task, ending the spell.
Possible manifestations:
‚ñ∂ Wraith: The spirit manifests as a wraith (see Old-School Essentials) and attempts to fight off intruders for up to 6 turns.
‚ñ∂ Warning: The spirit manifests at the caster‚Äôs current location, warning of the intrusion in the warded area and providing a broad description of the intruders.
‚ñ∂ Chilling fog: The spirit manifests as a chilling fog, filling a 10‚Ä≤ cube per level of the caster. It blocks normal vision and infravision and inflicts 1hp of cold damage per round to living creatures. The fog lasts for 1 turn.

This spell causes one or more undead monsters to be paralysed if they fail a saving throw versus spells. It may be cast in two ways:
1. Against an individual: The target‚Äôs saving throw is penalised by ‚Äì2.
2. Against a group: 1d4 individuals in the group are targeted.
Incorporeal undead: (e.g. spectres, wraiths) can be affected, but gain a +2 bonus to the saving throw.

The caster‚Äôs body enters a comatose trance as their life-force is transferred into a receptacle (any inanimate object within 30‚Ä≤), known as a magic jar. From there, the caster may attempt to possess the bodies of other creatures.
When the caster‚Äôs life-force is in the magic jar:
‚ñ∂ Possession: The caster may attempt to possess the body of another creature within 120‚Ä≤. The victim may save versus spells to resist possession. If the save is successful, the caster may not make another attempt to possess that victim for one turn. If the save fails, the caster‚Äôs life-force leaves the magic jar and enters the victim, possessing it.
‚ñ∂ Returning: The caster may choose to return to their own body at any time, ending the spell.
‚ñ∂ If the magic jar is destroyed: The caster dies.
‚ñ∂ If the caster‚Äôs own body is destroyed: Their life-force is stranded in the magic jar.
When the caster‚Äôs life-force is possessing a victim:
‚ñ∂ Control: The caster gains full control over the victim‚Äôs body, but is not able to make the victim cast spells.
‚ñ∂ If the magic jar is destroyed: The spell ends and the caster‚Äôs life-force is trapped in the possessed body.
‚ñ∂ If the possessed victim is killed: The caster‚Äôs life-force returns to the magic jar.
‚ñ∂ Dispelling: Dispel evil forces the caster‚Äôs life-force back into the magic jar.
‚ñ∂ If the caster‚Äôs own body is destroyed: Their life-force is stranded in the body of the creature being possessed.

The caster briefly enters a trance, their spirit drifting to observe a distant place or object brought to mind.
The clarity of the vision: Depends on the caster‚Äôs familiarity with the subject.
Detecting the caster: Any persons present at the site being viewed experience a brief chill as the caster‚Äôs spirit arrives. Those who can see invisible detect the caster‚Äôs spirit as a faint shimmering outline.
Attacking the caster: The caster‚Äôs spirit has AC 5 [14] and can only be harmed by magic and magic weapons. If it is struck, the caster suffers damage and the spell ends.
