Turning the caster: The caster‚Äôs spirit can be turned as a 4 HD undead monster, ending the spell if successful.
Obstructions: A thin layer of lead blocks this spell.
Awakening: If the caster is awoken from the trance, the spell is cut short.

The caster invokes Orcus, lord of the undead, who sends a number of his undead servitors to the caster‚Äôs aid.
Monsters summoned: Roll 1d6 on the table below to determine which monsters appear.
1d6 Monsters Summoned
1 16 skeletons
2 8 zombies
3 8 ghouls
4 5 wights
5 4 wraiths
6 3 mummies
Concentration: Is required to command summoned undead.
Dismissing: While control over the undead is maintained, the caster may dismiss them at any time, sending them back to their master, Orcus.
Disruption: If the caster moves at more than half speed or their concentration is disturbed, the command over the undead ends. The monsters are, henceforth, free-willed entities and will immediately try to kill the caster and any who get in their way.
Dispelling: Summoned undead may be dispelled by dispel magic or dispel evil.
Restrictions: The caster may cast this spell at most once per day.

This spell cloaks undead monsters with an illusion making them appear alive.
Subjects: 1 undead monster per level of the caster.
Appearance: Each subject appears as it did in life. The illusion veils all the signs of death, including deathly odours.
Behaviour: Subjects‚Äô behaviour and intelligence are not altered. For example, while a skeleton can be veiled to appear as a living person, it remains mindless and unable to speak.
Detecting: Only magic (e.g. detect undead, detect illusion) can reveal the veil.
Undead status: In all other respects, the subjects are still treated as undead. For example, they can be turned and are affected by spells such as command undead.

A sinister barrier of pure darkness manifests at a location of the caster‚Äôs choosing.
Size: 5‚Ä≤ thick, 20‚Ä≤ high, and up to 20‚Ä≤ long per caster level.
Darkness: The wall blocks both normal and infravision.
Touching: Anyone touching the wall must save versus spells or flee in terror for 1d6 rounds.
Passing through: Anyone not afflicted by terror upon touching the wall may attempt to pass through, incurring a second save versus spells. If this save fails, the creature is paralysed (magically frozen; unable to move or speak) and remains stuck in the darkness of the wall until its duration ends.
Exceptions: The caster, undead creatures, and creatures with an affinity for darkness or shadow are unhindered by the wall.
Concentration: The spell lasts as long as the caster concentrates and performs no other actions. Once concentration ends, the wall persists for 6 turns.

A single object or creature of normal bone is hardened with the resilience of steel.
Armour Class: The subject‚Äôs AC improves by 4 points.
Mundane damage resistance: The subject takes half damage from non-magical attacks.
Metal-affecting magic: May target the subject.

The caster is rendered immune to much physical harm, their heart and breathing stopping and their blood ceasing to flow.
Regeneration: The caster regenerates 1 hit point at the start of each round. Even damage that reduces the caster‚Äôs hit points below 0 can be regenerated while the spell lasts. The caster falls unconscious upon reaching 0hp, but awakens once they regenerate to 1hp.
Attacks: Weapons (including natural weapons such as claws and bites) inflict but a single point of damage. Magic weapons also inflict their magical ‚Äúplus‚Äù bonus (e.g. a sword +2 would inflict a total of 3 damage to the caster).
Energy: Damage from fire, electricity, cold, and acid is halved.
Immunities: The caster is unaffected by drowning, gases, paralysis, and energy drain.
Poison: Has no effect on the caster, but lingers in the system and, unless neutralised by other means, takes effect once the spell ends.
Saving throws: The caster gains a +4 bonus to saves versus death and paralysis.

Up to 4d8 Hit Dice of creatures within a 60‚Ä≤ cube area must save versus death or die, instantly.
Restrictions: Undead and creatures with greater than 7 Hit Dice are unaffected.

All living creatures within range (excluding the caster) must save versus spells or be surrounded with a shimmering black aura.
Effect: While the spell lasts, affected creatures are unable to gain hit points due to regeneration or healing of any kind (natural or magical).

The creature touched permanently loses one experience level (or Hit Die).
Attack roll: In combat, a melee attack roll is required. If the attack misses, the spell is wasted.
Effects: The victim loses one Hit Die of hit points, as well as all other benefits due to the drained level (e.g. spells, saving throws, etc.). A character‚Äôs XP is reduced to halfway between the former and new levels. A person drained of all levels becomes a zombie in 1d4 days, under the control of the caster.
Restrictions: Non-living targets (including undead) are not affected.

Necromancer.spell_duration: Permanent until fulfilled / Instant (remove eternal quest)
Necromancer.description:
The caster commands a single subject to perform a specific quest or task.
Examples of quests: Rescuing a prisoner, killing a specific monster, bringing a magic item to the caster, or going on a journey to an oracle.
Suicidal quests: The prescribed quest must not be obviously suicidal.
Saving throw: The subject may save versus spells to resist the eternal quest.
Refusal: The subject must undertake the quest or slowly perish. Every day in which the subject does not pursue the quest, their maximum hit points are reduced by 1. If the subject dies, they rise as an undead monster of Hit Dice equal to half their level and continue the quest. The type of undead should be chosen by the referee.
Completion: Once the task is completed, the spell ends. If the subject is undead, they perish, released into death. If they are alive, their maximum hit points are restored to normal.

This spell dispels an active eternal quest spell and any incurred penalties.
Automatic dispelling: An eternal quest placed by a lower level caster is automatically dispelled.
Chance of success: An eternal quest created by a higher level caster has a 5% chance per level difference of not being dispelled.

The caster‚Äôs eyes turn pure black, bringing death to any they gaze upon.
Gaze attack: Once per round, the caster may gaze at a living target within 30‚Ä≤. The gaze may be used in addition to other attacks and actions.
Effects: The target must save versus death or suffer 2d6 damage. The body of a target killed by the gaze disintegrates into black sludge.
Expiration: When the spell ends, there is a 1-in-20 chance of the caster being rendered blind for 1d6 hours.

Necromancer.spell_range: The caster or a creature touched
Necromancer.description:
The subject is rendered immune to the special attacks of all undead creatures.
Special attacks: The immunity includes paralysis, energy drain, ability score drain, disease, poison, fear effects, etc.
Normal attacks: Undead can still harm the subject with attacks that inflict damage. For example, the claw attacks of a ghoul still inflict 1d3 damage, but do not inflict paralysis.
Spells: The subject does not gain immunity to spells cast by undead creatures, but gains a +2 bonus to saving throws against them.

By making a bargain with the powers of death, the caster can exchange one soul for another, bringing a recently deceased human or demihuman back to life in return for a sacrifice of equal magnitude.
Time limit: The caster can raise a person who has been dead for no longer than four days per level of the caster above 10th. For example, a 13th level caster can revive a character who has been dead for twelve days (three levels above 10th √ó four days).
Ritual sacrifice: The spell is cast as a ritual lasting 1 turn, during which a number of intelligent beings must be sacrificed. Their total Hit Dice must equal that of the person to be resurrected.
Weakness: Returning from death is an ordeal. Until the subject gets two full weeks of bed rest, they have 1 hit point, move at half the normal rate, cannot carry heavy items, and cannot attack, cast spells, or use other class abilities. This period of weakness may not be shortened by any magical healing.

Cast in a graveyard or at the site of a battle, this spell causes a troop of skeletons to reanimate and rise up from the earth, ready to do the caster‚Äôs bidding.
Number: Up to 4 skeletons per level of the caster are reanimated.
Weapons: The skeletal legion is equipped with any weapons they were buried with.
Expiration: When the duration ends, the raised skeletons and their weaponry crumble to dust.
Skeleton stats: AC 7 [12], HD 1 (4hp), Att 1 √ó weapon (1d6 or by weapon), THAC0 19 [0], MV 60‚Ä≤ (20‚Ä≤), SV D12 W13 P14 B15 S16 (1), ML 12, AL Chaotic, XP 10
Undead traits: Usually make no noise. Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).

This spell summons 2d6 guardian spirits from the realm of the dead. The spirits are faintly visible, whirling around the caster, forming a protective shield against magic.
Spell reflection: When the caster is targeted by a spell, one of the guardian spirits reflects it back at the character who cast it. The guardian spirit perishes.
Expiration: Once all guardian spirits have reflected a spell, spirit shield ends.
Turning: The guardian spirits can be turned, being treated as 8 HD undead.

One or more undead monsters of the caster‚Äôs choosing become indestructible for the duration.
Hit Dice limit: Up to 1 HD of undead per level of the caster are affected. Undead monsters of more than 3 HD cannot be affected.
Regeneration: If an affected monster is killed, it rises again the following round, regaining 1d8 hit points.
Destruction: Affected monsters which are utterly destroyed (e.g. disintegrated, destroyed by a D result on a turning attempt) do not regenerate.

special_abilities: Poison: There is a 50% chance of the snakes being poisonous.
When killed: Revert back to sticks.

stat_block.Hit_Dice: 1 (HD one greater than creature in life)

special_abilities: Undead: Usually make no noise.
Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Undead: Usually make no noise.
Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Undead: Usually make no noise.
Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Initiative: Always lose (no roll).
Undead: Usually make no noise. Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Undead: Usually make no noise.
Immune to biological effects (e.g. poison) and mind-affecting / mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Whirlwind: Creatures with less than 2HD swept aside (save versus death).
Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Harm flying creatures: Inflict extra 1d8 damage.

stat_block.Attack_Description: Can be directed to attack (illusory damage only)

special_abilities: Inflicts no real damage. Effects (e.g., apparent death, petrification) last 1d4 turns. Targets save versus spells for no effect.
Leader: Groups of 4+ are led by a higher level cleric (1d10: 1‚Äì4: 2nd level, 5‚Äì7: 3rd level, 8‚Äì9: 4th level, 10: 5th level). Choose or roll the leader‚Äôs spells.
Monsters.description: 1st level clerics on a quest for their deity.

special_abilities: Leader: Groups of 4+ are led by a higher level cleric (1d10: 1‚Äì4: 2nd level, 5‚Äì7: 3rd level, 8‚Äì9: 4th level, 10: 5th level). Choose or roll the leader‚Äôs spells.
Monsters.description: 1st level clerics on a quest for their deity.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Tracking: Without error.
Detect invisible creatures: Within 60‚Äô.
Immunity: Unharmed by gas; unaffected by charm, hold, and sleep spells.
Monsters.description: Constructed in the form of giant cats (e.g. lions or tigers).

special_abilities: Poison: Causes death (save vs poison).
Cold immunity: Unharmed by cold-based attacks.
Monsters.description: 8‚Äô long giant snakes with a head at each end of their body. Dwell in all but the most extreme climes. Will usually only attack if cornered or surprised.
Monsters.habitat: All but the most extreme climes

special_abilities: Ambush: Hide just beneath the surface of the ground and burst out when something walks above.
Acid: Inflicts 1d4 damage per round until washed off or the victim dies.
Acid squirt: Once per day, may squirt digestive acid at a target up to 30‚Äô away. Save versus breath for half damage.
Monsters.description: 10‚Äô‚Äì20‚Äô long, many-legged, burrowing insects with tough shells and shiny black eyes. Consume soil but also enjoy fresh meat. Dwell in forests and fertile lands.

special_abilities: Ambush: Hide just beneath the surface of the ground and burst out when something walks above.
Acid: Inflicts 1d4 damage per round until washed off or the victim dies.
Acid squirt: Once per day, may squirt digestive acid at a target up to 30‚Äô away. Save versus breath for half damage.

special_abilities: Ambush: Hide just beneath the surface of the ground and burst out when something walks above.
Acid: Inflicts 1d4 damage per round until washed off or the victim dies.
Acid squirt: Once per day, may squirt digestive acid at a target up to 30‚Äô away. Save versus breath for half damage.
Monsters.description: 10‚Äô‚Äì20‚Äô long, many-legged, burrowing insects with tough shells and shiny black eyes. Consume soil but also enjoy fresh meat. Dwell in forests and fertile lands.

special_abilities: Trickery: Use disguise or trickery to surprise victims.
Leader: May have a leader of 2nd level or higher (any human class).
Hoard: Only have treasure type A when encountered in their wilderness lair.
Monsters.description: NPC thieves who live by robbery.

special_abilities: Undead: Make no noise, until they attack. Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Energy immunity: Unharmed by cold-based or electrical attacks.
Wail: All within 30‚Äô must save versus death or die. Usable once per day and only during the hours of darkness.
Origin: Legends say that banshees are the spirits of wicked female elves.
Monsters.description: Incorporeal female spirits that linger after death in order to cause suffering to the living. Haunt desolate moors.

special_abilities: Surprise: Characters surprised by a basilisk meet its gaze.
Petrifying touch: Anyone touched by a basilisk is turned to stone (save vs petrify).
Petrifying gaze: Anyone meeting a basilisk‚Äôs gaze is turned to stone (save versus petrify). Unless averting eyes or using a mirror, characters in melee are affected each round.
Averting eyes: ‚Äì4 penalty to hit; the basilisk gains a +2 bonus to attack.

Mirrors: The reflection of a basilisk is harmless. Fighting by looking in a mirror incurs a ‚Äì1 penalty to attack. If a basilisk sees its own reflection (2-in-6 chance), it must save or be petrified.
Monsters.description: 10‚Äô long, serpentine lizards. Unintelligent, but highly magical. Dwell in caverns and twisted brambles.

special_abilities: Echolocation: Unaffected by effects that impair, modify, or rely on sight. Blinded by magical silence.
Swarm: 10 bats can swarm around a target‚Äôs head, causing confusion: ‚Äì2 to attack rolls and saves; unable to cast spells.
Attacks: As normal human.
Flighty: Unless magically summoned or controlled, normal bats check morale every round.
Males: 1/4 of animals are males, whose bite does extra damage.
Tip boats: 50% likely to emerge under canoes or small boats, tipping them over.
Submersion: Lurk underwater. Can remain submerged for up to 30 minutes.
Monsters.description: Massive, thick-skinned pachyderms that live in tropical rivers and lakes. Herbivorous but aggressively territorial. Gargantuan (20‚Äô long) hippos, found in Lost World settings.

special_abilities: Battle rage: +2 to hit humans and similar humanoids (e.g. orcs, goblins). Rage sometimes makes them attack their allies.
Hoard: Only have treasure type B when encountered in the wilderness.
Monsters.description: Fighters who enter a rage in battle. They never take prisoners.

special_abilities: Bear hug: If a victim is hit by both claw attacks in the same round, the bear hugs for an extra 2d8 automatic damage.
Defensive: Adults will protect their young with their lives, but otherwise only attack if cornered.
Camp raids: Sometimes raid camps for food (especially fish and sweet treats).
Monsters.description: 6‚Äô tall; favour eating berries and roots.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 60‚Äô long line of acid.
Language and spells: 20%; 4 √ó 1st level.
Sleeping: 40%.
Monsters.description: Dwell in swamps and marshes.

special_abilities: Illusion immunity: Completely unaffected by illusions and phantasms.
Grapple: If a victim is hit by all three of a hag‚Äôs attacks in the same round, they are seized and suffer automatic damage (3d8 + 9) each subsequent round.
Cloak true form: Can cloak true appearance with an illusory form.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 100‚Äô long line of lightning.

Sleeping: 20%.
Monsters.description: Favour open plains and deserts.
Omnivorous wild boars that dwell primarily in forests. Can be irascible and dangerous, if disturbed.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.

Immunity: Unharmed by gas; unaffected by charm, hold, and sleep spells.
Monsters.description: 6‚Äô tall constructs of human bone, crafted into a humanoid shape. Have four arms, attached at different places on the torso.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 70‚Äô long cone of sleep gas (save versus breath or fall asleep for 4d4 turns) or cloud of fear gas (save versus breath or flee for 2 turns).
Language & spells: 20%; 4 √ó 1st level.
Sleeping: 40%.

special_abilities: mounted on riding horses and has: chainmail, shield, sword.
Monsters.description: Outlaws and mercenaries who make a living by raiding settlements and attacking travellers.

leather armour, shield, sword, shortbow.
Monsters.description: Outlaws and mercenaries who make a living by raiding settlements and attacking travellers.

special_abilities: For every 20 brigands, there is a leader (2nd level fighter).

Breath weapon: 100‚Äô long line of lightning (all caught in the area suffer damage equal to the dragon‚Äôs current hit points‚Äîsave versus breath for half) or cloud of repulsion gas (save versus breath or pushed 60‚Äô away per round for 6 rounds).

Sleeping: 20%.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.

Fire immunity: Unharmed by fire.
Immunity: Unharmed by gas; unaffected by charm, hold, and sleep spells.

special_abilities: Surprise: Never surprised.

special_abilities: Arms: 60% of group have: leather armour, sword; 30% have: leather armour, sword, crossbow; 10% have: chainmail, sword, crossbow.

30% chance of a magic-user (level 1d2 + 9); 25% chance of a cleric (8th level).
For every 30 buccaneers, there is a 4th level fighter.
Surprise: On a 1‚Äì3, due to stealth.

special_abilities: Ravenous: Will attack anything living.

Origin: Rumoured to be the result of a wizard‚Äôs experiments in crossbreeding turtles, armadillos, and demons.
Monsters.description: 15‚Äô long, hard-shelled reptiles with huge maws, tiny eyes, and a shark-like crest upon the back. Have a ravenous appetite for the flesh of horses and humanoids (except elves). Love to dig halflings and gnomes out of their burrows.

special_abilities: Blood scent: Can detect blood in water up to 300‚Äô away.

Monsters.description: 8‚Äô long; brown colouration. Attack by ramming, then biting the stunned prey.

special_abilities: Swallow whole: On a natural 19 or 20 attack roll. Inside the monster‚Äôs belly: suffer 1d8 damage per round (until the caecilia dies); may attack with a dagger at ‚Äì4 to hit; body digested in 6 turns after death.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a roll of 1, a random character meets the catoblepas‚Äô gaze.

special_abilities: Weapons: Bows, clubs, lances.

stat_block.Attack_Description: 2 √ó claw (1d3), goat: 1 √ó gore (2d4), lion: 1 √ó bite (2d4), dragon: 1 √ó bite (3d4) or 1 √ó breath (3d6)

Undead: Make no noise, until they attack. Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).

Magic powers: Once per day each: a. Dispel magic: Ends spells of non-instantaneous duration within a 20‚Äô cube area. b. Fireball: 14d6 damage to all in a 20‚Äô radius area up to 240‚Äô away. Save versus spells for half damage. c. Wall of ice: Up to 1,200 sq ft, lasting 12 turns. Blocks creatures with less than 4 HD. Creatures with 4+ HD can break through but suffer 1d6 damage.

special_abilities: Mounted: On warhorses.

Characters of Lawful alignment may be asked to join the holy war. Dervishes are highly suspicious of those who refuse (without good reason).
Monsters.description: Fanatically religious, nomadic people who wander steppes and desert regions, living in tents.

stat_block.Attack_Description: 1 √ó gore (2d6) or 1 √ó weapon (1d6 or by weapon) or 1 √ó magic (charm)

special_abilities: Shapechange: Only at night.

Killing the devil swine breaks the charm.
Charmed victims: 1d4‚Äì1 accompany a devil swine.
Monsters.description: Corpulent humans who can change into huge swine. Love to eat human flesh. Lurk in isolated human settlements close to forests or marshes. Mundane damage immunity: In animal form, can only be harmed by silver weapons or magic. Languages: In human form, can speak normally. Infection: A character who loses more than 1/2 their hit points from lycanthropes‚Äô natural attacks (i.e. bites, claws) contracts lycanthropy. Humans become were-creatures of the same type (run by the referee, henceforth); non-humans die. The disease takes full effect in 2d12 days, showing signs of infection after half the time.

special_abilities: Training: At the referee‚Äôs discretion, captured cubs may be trained like dogs. Dire wolves are ferocious and extremely difficult to train.

special_abilities: Detect magic items: Up to 60‚Äô. Can differentiate items by power level.

special_abilities: Non-combatant: Will flee, if attacked.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 90‚Äô long, 30‚Äô wide cloud of steam. Can be used up to three times per day. All caught in the area suffer damage equal to the dragon turtle‚Äôs current hit points (save vs breath for half).

Monsters.description: Gargantuan sea monsters with the body and hard shell of a turtle and the head, tail, and legs of a dragon. Lurk in huge caves in the depths of the ocean, only rarely coming to the surface.

special_abilities: Roar: All within 120‚Äô must save versus paralysis or be weakened (‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls) for 2d6 rounds. Characters within 30‚Äô who fail the save are also deafened for the same duration.

Monsters.description: Small (5‚Äô tall at the shoulder) dragons with brass-coloured scales, small wings, and the head of a lion. Dreaded for their fearsome roar.

stat_block.Attack_Description: 1 √ó weapon (1d6 or by weapon) or 1 √ó bite (1d4 + poison)

Monsters.description: Giant (6‚Äô long), omnivorous, black ants.

special_abilities: Infravision: 90‚Äô.
Light sensitivity: Suffer a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls and a ‚Äì1 penalty to AC when in bright light (daylight, continual light).
Divine spells: Each Drow has either light or its reverse, darkness, memorized.
Spiders: 1-in-4 chance of being accompanied by 1d4 giant spiders.
Monsters.description: Slender, fey demihumans with pointed ears, jet black skin, and hair of silver or white. Also known as dark elves. Live in the deep places of the Underworld and worship strange, subterranean deities.

special_abilities: Infravision: 90‚Äô.

level 1d6 + 1 (See Characters: Drow).

special_abilities: Anti-magic ray: The central eye dispels magic up to 60‚Äô in front. Spell casting fails and ongoing spells and magic items are temporarily disabled. Characters within the ray cannot be affected by the rays from the eye stalks.
Attacking the central eye: AC 2 [17], 20hp (separate hp pool). If reduced to 0hp, the anti-magic ray ceases to function.

Eye stalks: Each stalk can shoot a magical ray up to once per round. Up to 4 stalks can fire in one direction at a time: a. Charm person: Range 120‚Äô. Save versus spells or be charmed: move towards the eye of terror (resisting those who try to prevent it); obey the eye‚Äôs commands (if understood); defend the eye; unable to cast spells or use magic items; unable to harm the eye. Killing the eye of terror breaks the charm. b. Charm monster: As charm person, but affects any creature (except undead). c. Sleep: Range 240‚Äô. One creature of 4+1 HD or 2d8 Hit Dice of creatures of 4 HD or less fall asleep for 4d4 turns. d. Telekinesis: Range 120‚Äô. Move up to 5,000 coins of weight up to 20‚Äô per round. Creatures may save vs spells. e. Petrify: Range 30‚Äô. Save versus petrification or turn to stone. f. Disintegrate: Range 20‚Äô. Save versus death or be annihilated. g. Cause fear: Range 120‚Äô. Save versus spells or flee for 2 turns. h. Slow: Range 240‚Äô. Save versus spells or move and attack at half speed for 3 turns. i. Cause serious wounds: Range 60‚Äô. Inflicts 2d6+2 damage. j. Death spell: Range 40‚Äô. Up to 4d8 HD of creatures within a 60‚Äô cube area must save versus death or die instantly. Undead or creatures with greater than 7 HD are unaffected.
Attacking the eye stalks: AC 7 [12], 12hp (separate hp pool each). Successful attacks damage a random eye stalk. If reduced to 0hp, a stalk‚Äôs ray cannot function.
Eye regeneration: Disabled eyes are regenerated in 2d4 days.

special_abilities: Blinding ray: The central eye emits a ray of blinding light up to 60‚Äô in front. Characters must save versus death or be paralysed for 1d10 rounds.

Eye stalks: Each stalk can shoot a magical ray up to once per round: a. Hold person: Range 120‚Äô. Save versus spells or be paralysed for 6 turns. May target 1d4 creatures in a group or an individual (‚Äì2 to the save). Affects persons of up to 4+1 HD. b. Hold monster: As hold person, but affects any creature (except undead).

Attacking the eye stalks: AC 5 [14], 12hp (separate hp pool each). Successful attacks damage a random eye stalk. If reduced to 0hp, a stalk‚Äôs magic ray cannot function.

special_abilities: Boulder throwing: Up to 200‚Äô.

special_abilities: Heat aura: All creatures within 20‚Äô suffer 1d8 damage per round.

Damage immunity: Unharmed by non-magical blunt weapons.

Break down doors: Can easily smash through doors.
Monsters.description: Gargantuan (30‚Äô long) grey slugs with rasp-like tongues and acidic spit. Voracious predators that dwell underground.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì4, due to hiding motionless underwater.
Long neck: Can bite up to 10‚Äô away.
Monsters.description: Giant (10‚Äô long), aggressive predatory turtles that lurk in the shallows of lakes and large rivers.

stat_block.Attack_Description: 8 √ó small tentacle (1d4 + constriction), 2 √ó large tentacle (1d4 + constriction or 1d10 hull damage), 1 √ó beak (1d10 or 2 hull damage)

special_abilities: Crush boats: 25% likely to wrap the 2 large tentacles around a boat, doing 1d10 hull damage per tentacle. When the large tentacles are grappling a boat, in subsequent rounds, the beak inflicts 2 points of hull damage automatically.
Grab crew: 75% likely to grab crew from the deck and drag them underwater to be eaten.
Constriction: Tentacles grab and constrict after a hit. 1d4 automatic damage per round.
Severing tentacles: Requires a hit that inflicts 6 or more damage (8 small tentacles) or 10 or more damage (2 large tentacles).
Ink cloud: When escaping, can emit a cloud of black ink (60‚Äô diameter) and jet away at 3 times normal speed. Maximum twice a day.
Monsters.description: Giant, ten-armed cephalopods. Two of the ten arms are larger, and may be used to attack ships. Dwell in the depths of the sea, only surface to find prey.

special_abilities: Swallow whole: On a natural 18, 19, or 20 attack roll. Inside the fish‚Äôs belly: suffer 2d6 damage per round (until the fish dies); save versus death or be paralysed; may attack with sharp weapons at ‚Äì4 to hit (inside belly has AC 7 [12]); body digested in 6 turns after death.
Monsters.description: Huge (nearly 30‚Äô long), aggressive fish with armour plating.

special_abilities: Cling: Can walk on walls and ceilings.
Jaw clamp: Inflicts double damage on an attack roll of 20.
Monsters.description: 20‚Äô long, highly aggressive lizards that dwell exclusively underground.
8‚Äô long saltwater fish with a bony sword on the snout. Typically non-aggressive.

special_abilities: Poison: Save vs poison or dance for 2d6 turns (suffering from painful, jerking spasms that resemble a macabre dance).
Onlookers: Viewers of one affected by the poison must save versus spells or begin dancing in the same fashion, for as long as the poisoned victim.
Dancing: Those affected suffer a ‚Äì4 penalty to attack rolls and AC. After 5 turns of dancing, they become exhausted: fall to the ground, helpless.
Monsters.description: 7‚Äô long, hairy hunting spiders that resemble tarantulas. Magical in nature.
Carnivorous, 4‚Äô long, tiger-striped beetles with powerful, crushing mandibles. Hunt robber flies, but sometimes eat humans.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì3, in forests or dark dungeons, due to the ability to change colour to match their surroundings.
Sticky tongue: Attack up to 15‚Äô away. On a hit, prey (up to dwarf size) is dragged to the mouth and bitten.

Swallow whole: A natural 20 attack roll indicates a small victim is swallowed. Inside the toad‚Äôs belly: suffer 1d6 damage per round (until the toad dies); may attack with sharp weapons at ‚Äì4 to hit; body digested in 6 turns after death.
Monsters.description: Warty amphibians with long, sticky tongues. As large as a great hound, weighing 150 to 250 pounds.

special_abilities: Infravision: 90‚Äô. Granted by retractable eye membranes.
Monsters.description: 8‚Äô long, iguana-like, carnivorous lizards with olive scales and a ridge of white spikes along the back. Have been known to attack humans.

special_abilities: Echolocation: Unaffected by effects that impair, modify, or rely on sight. Blinded by magical silence.
Unconsciousness: For 1d10 rounds (save versus paralysis).

Blood drain: A vampire bat may drain blood from an unconscious victim: 1d4 hit points automatic damage per round. A victim killed by blood drain becomes undead (possibly a vampire) after 24 hours (save versus spells).
Poison: Causes permanent paralysis and death after 1d4 days (save vs poison).
Vulnerable to fire: If a wasp is damaged with fire (e.g. burning oil, torches), its wings are burned off.
Nests: Some giant wasps build nests of wood pulp. These lairs house 2d20 wasps.
Monsters.description: 5‚Äô long, highly aggressive, carnivorous insects. Paralyse creatures with their sting then lay eggs in the victim, which is then devoured by the larvae as they hatch. Dwell in warm and temperate climates.

special_abilities: Infravision: 30‚Äô.
Blood sucking: Upon a successful attack, locks onto the victim and drains its blood: 2d4 automatic damage per round.
Detaching: If the weasel or victim dies.
Tracking: By scent, favouring wounded prey.
Treasure: Found in their lair on bodies of victims.
Monsters.description: 8‚Äô to 9‚Äô long, vicious, predatory mammals with rich fur of brown, gold, or white. Dwell in subterranean tunnels, hunting alone or in small groups.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì5, if the Mouther remains motionless with eyes and mouths closed. Appears like a mound of earth.
Attaching: On a successful bite attack, the mouth locks onto the victim and inflicts 1 damage in subsequent rounds.
Detach: If Mouther or victim dies.
Slip: 1-in-6 chance of victim falling to the ground. The Mouther then immediately oozes on top of the victim and attacks with 6 more mouths.

Gibbering: All within 60‚Äô who hear the babbling of dozens of mouths must save versus spells or be maddened. Victims behave randomly as long as the gibbering continues; roll 1d8 each round. 1: move randomly, 2‚Äì5: no action, 6‚Äì7: attack nearest creature, 8: flee.
Monsters.description: 5‚Äô mounds of rubbery jelly with hundreds of deranged eyes and mouths. Dwell in dark, cold, dank places. Consume all living matter they come across.
Lazy, humanoid hyenas of low intelligence that live by intimidation and theft. Legends say that gnolls were magically created by a wizard who crossbred gnomes and trolls.
Groups of 20+ are led by a gnoll with 3HD (16hp).

stat_block.Morale_Rating: 8 (10 in sight of leader or chieftain)

special_abilities: Weapons: Typically use war hammers and crossbows.
Infravision: 90‚Äô.
Hate kobolds: Normally attack on sight.
Mines and machines: Love machinery, mining, gold, and gems. May make foolish decisions to obtain precious items. War with goblins and kobolds over precious metals.
Monsters.description: Short demihumans with long noses and beards. Smaller cousins of dwarves, whom they get along with. Prefer to live in burrows in a non-mountainous country.
1d6 3HD (1d4 + 9hp) bodyguards live in the gnome lair.

special_abilities: The chieftain gains a +1 bonus to damage.
Monsters.description: A 4HD (18hp) chieftain lives in the gnome lair.
A 2HD (11hp) leader is present for every 20 gnomes.

special_abilities: Infravision: 90‚Äô.
Hate the sun: ‚Äì1 to hit in full daylight.
Wolf riders: 20% of goblin groups encountered have wolf riders: ¬º of the group mounted on dire wolves.
Hate dwarves: Attack on sight.
Hoard: Only have treasure type C when encountered in the wilderness or in their lair.
Monsters.description: Small, grotesque humanoids with pallid, earth-coloured skin and glowing, red eyes. Dwell underground.

special_abilities: Do not suffer attack penalties in daylight.
Monsters.description: 2d6 2HD (2d6hp) bodyguards live in the goblin lair.

special_abilities: Do not suffer attack penalties in daylight.
The king gains a +1 bonus to damage.
Monsters.description: A 3HD (15hp) king lives in the goblin lair.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 90‚Äô long cone of fire or cloud of chlorine gas.
Language and spells: 100%; 4 √ó 1st level, 4 √ó 2nd level, 4 √ó 3rd level.
Sleeping: 5%.
Shape changing: May take on the form of a person or animal.
Monsters.description: May be encountered in any terrain, often in the guise of a person or animal.

special_abilities: Charge: When not in melee. Requires a clear run of at least 20 yards. Gore inflicts double damage.
Petrifying breath: Cloud 60‚Äô long, 10‚Äô wide. All in the cloud are turned to stone (save versus petrify to avoid). Unharmed by own breath.
Monsters.description: Magical monsters that resemble iron-scaled bulls. Dwell in plains or foothills.

special_abilities: Rending: If a victim is hit by both fists in the same round, the gorilla rends for an extra 1d6 automatic damage.
Monsters.description: Large (6‚Äô tall), heavy-set apes that dwell in isolated jungles. Peaceful and shy.

special_abilities: Blood scent: Can detect blood in water up to 300‚Äô away.

Monsters.description: 30‚Äô long (or bigger!); grey colouration with white belly. Sometimes they attack small boats.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Size: 32‚Äô tall, 8‚Äô across.
Whirlwind: Creatures with less than 2HD swept aside (save versus death).
Harm flying creatures: Inflict extra 1d8 damage.
Monsters.description: Huge vortexes of whirling air.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.

It Moves at 240‚Äô (80‚Äô). 3d12 damage to all in path. Creatures with less than 5 HD are slain (save versus death). b. Gaseous form c. Invisibility d. Illusion: Visual and audial. If killed: Returns to plane of air.
Monsters.description: Mighty rulers (sometimes called pashas) of the race of djinn‚Äîmagical, intelligent beings from the elemental plane of air. Tall humanoids wreathed in clouds.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.

Hoard: Only have treasure type B when encountered in the wilderness.
Monsters.description: Little, furry-footed demihumans who dwell in small villages (30‚Äì300 occupants).
A militia of 5d4 2HD guards is also present in halfling villages.

special_abilities: Charm: Anyone who hears the song of a group of harpies must save versus spells or be charmed: move towards the harpies (resisting those who try to prevent it); defend the harpies; obey the harpies‚Äô commands (if understood); unable to cast spells or use magic items; unable to harm the harpies. special_abilities: Swoop: Can dive onto victims visible from above. If the victim is surprised, the attack inflicts double damage. On an attack roll of 18 or more, the victim can be carried away (if of appropriate size).

Monsters.description: Hairy, brutish, 12‚Äô tall humanoids of low intelligence. Dwell in foothills. Known to attack human settlements to steal food.

special_abilities: Mounts: Used as mounts by aquatic humanoids.
Monsters.description: Intelligent aquatic horses with two finned forelegs and a long, fish-like tail.

special_abilities: Hate pegasi: Will usually attack.

Monsters.description: Fantastic creatures combining the features of a giant eagle (head and forequarters) and a horse. Nest among craggy rocks.

special_abilities: Males: 1/4 of animals are males, whose bite does extra damage.

Submersion: Lurk underwater. Can remain submerged for up to 15 minutes.

Confusion: Victims behave randomly; roll 1d8 each round. 1: move randomly, 2‚Äì5: no action, 6‚Äì7: attack nearest creature, 8: flee.

Size: 10‚Äô √ó 30‚Äô area, typically.

Diving into water: Suffer damage for one round, then attached insects drown.

1d6 1+1HD (6hp) bodyguards live in the kobold lair.

Monsters.description: Hovering brains (5‚Äô across) with an octopus-like beak and a cluster of 10 spiny, 6‚Äô-long tentacles hanging below. Dwell in dungeons and ruins.

Monsters.description: Centaur-like monsters with the legs and body of a beast and the upper body and head of a woman. Dwell in ruins and deserts. Prey on humanoids, draining their blood and consuming their flesh.

special_abilities: Feeding frenzy: Attracted to the scent of blood or violent movement in the water.
Monsters.description: Large reptiles that are ungainly on land and live primarily in water, lurking just beneath the surface of subtropical swamps and lazy rivers. 20‚Äô or more long. May attack small water craft (canoes, rafts). If hungry, attack any creatures that venture into the water.

special_abilities: Stampede: Herds of 20 or more can trample those in their path. 3-in-4 chance each round. +4 to hit human-sized or smaller creatures. 1d20 damage.

Monsters.description: For example: elk or moose.

special_abilities: Alignment reaction: ‚Äì1 to reaction rolls versus Neutral characters; ‚Äì2 versus Chaotic characters.

special_abilities: Surprise: Acute hearing prevents surprise. Always surprise others, if invisible.

No concentration required. Remains until touched or dispelled. e. Create food and drink: For 12 humans and mounts for one day. f. Conjure metallic objects: Up to 1,000 coins in weight. Temporary: hardness determines duration (gold: 1 day; iron: 1 round). g. Conjure soft goods / wooden objects: Up to 1,000 coins weight. Permanent.

Monsters.description: Weird monsters with a stag-like body, a lion-like tail, and a badger-like head. Have jagged ridges of bone in place of teeth. Dwell in ruins and desolate wilds.

special_abilities: Undead: Make no noise, until they attack. Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).

Monsters.description: Mighty magic-users whose evil magic has rendered them immortal in undeath, their souls stored in a phylactery. Appear as a skeletal figure dressed in decaying finery. A cold fire burns in their eyes. Ruthlessly pursue their arcane research in vast dungeons or ruined palaces.

special_abilities: Pursuit: Always pursue prey that flees.

special_abilities: Weapons: Crossbows and lances.

For every 5 merchants, 2 lieutenants are present (2nd‚Äì3rd level fighters). Equipped as guards.

special_abilities: Weapons: Spears, tridents, or daggers.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì4, due to camouflage.

special_abilities: Mimicry: Can change form to appear like any object of stone or wood.

Forced acts that are self-destructive or against the victim‚Äôs alignment allow another save to break the mind control. b. special_abilities: Pursuit: Always pursue prey that flees.

Inquisitive: May follow PCs out of curiosity.

stat_block.Attack_Description: 5 √ó bite (damage by head colour) or breath, 1 √ó tail sting (1d6 + poison)

Black head: Bite: 2d10 damage. Breath: 60‚Äô long line of acid, 5‚Äô wide.
Green head: Bite: 3d8 damage. Breath: Cloud of chlorine gas, 50‚Äô long, 40‚Äô wide, 20‚Äô high.

Magic-user spells: White head: 2 √ó 1st level, black head: 2 √ó 2nd level, green head: 2 √ó 3rd level, blue head: 2 √ó 4th level, red head: 2 √ó 5th level.
Disabling heads: Heads may be targeted individually. An attack that inflicts 10 or more damage disables a head (unable to attack, breathe, or cast spells).

special_abilities: Paralyse with terror: Anyone seeing a mummy must save versus paralysis or be paralysed with terror. Paralysis is broken if the mummy attacks or goes out of sight.

Damage immunity: Only harmed by fire or magic. All damage is reduced by half.
Undead: Make no noise, until they attack. Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Monsters.description: Undead humanoids wrapped in funerary bandages. Haunt ruins and tombs.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì3, due to great skill at hiding and camouflage. Requires 1 turn of preparation.
Mimicry: Can mimic the sound of any monster or animal.
Pick pockets: 70% chance of success, penalised by 5% for every level of the victim above 5th. A roll of more than twice the percentage required for success means that the attempted theft is noticed.

Monsters.description: Humanoids with mismatched body parts of many different creatures (e.g. reptiles, crustaceans, birds, mammals, etc.). Each individual has a unique appearance. Shunned by other species, they live in hiding within large settlements or band together and dwell in ruins.

special_abilities: A 4 HD chieftain (with 18hp) rules groups of 40+.
Groups of 10+ are led by an individual with 2 HD (with 9hp).
Telepathy: Can communicate non-verbally with any sentient being within 120‚Äô.
Light sensitivity: Suffer a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls and a ‚Äì1 penalty to AC when in bright light (daylight, continual light).
Monsters.description: Mycelians are 4‚Äô tall humanoid mushrooms, with tall stems, wide, flat caps, and beady eyes amid their gills. They have no mouths, but communicate telepathically. They dwell in lightless caverns deep underground.

special_abilities: A Mycelian lair is ruled by a 10‚Äô tall king with 6 HD (27hp).

Six times per day, the king can spray a spore cloud onto a target within 20‚Äô, which must save versus poison. The king‚Äôs spore cloud has the effect either of pacifying the target (unable to move or act for 6 rounds) or of causing hallucinations for 6 turns (roll 1d3, 1: flee in terror, 2. cower and babble, 3: attempt to kill the nearest creature).
Fungal zombies: Lair is guarded by 1d6 fungal zombies animated by the king. These behave as normal zombies, but are not undead and cannot be turned.
Groups of 10+ are led by a 6‚Äô tall Mycelian with 3 HD (13hp).
Three times per day, a leader can spray a spore cloud onto a target within 20‚Äô, which must save versus poison or become completely passive, unable to act or move for 3 rounds.
Horn: Is worth 1d6 √ó 1,000gp. Rumours say a narwhal‚Äôs horn vibrates when evil is near.
Monsters.description: 15‚Äô long, intelligent, magical whales with grey to white skin and an 8‚Äô long, spiralling horn on their nose. Live independent and secretive lives in arctic waters.

special_abilities: Weapons: Prefer stone axes, stone hammers, clubs, or spears.
Racial animosity: Attack ogres on sight. Hate goblins and kobolds.
Pets: Sometimes keep white apes as pets (see Ape, White).
Monsters.description: Squat, powerful, primitive demihumans with ape-like faces. Dwell in caverns and hunt cave bears. Shy of contact with humans (with whom they are related), but friendly with dwarves and gnomes.
Two 6HD leaders (one male, one female) live in the neanderthal lair. They are 10‚Äô tall and of a related but distinct race.

special_abilities: Undead: Make no noise, until they attack. Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).

Surprise: If a Necrophidius surprises enemies, it begins to sway hypnotically. All who observe must save versus spells or be hypnotised for 1d4 rounds, unable to move or act. The Necrophidius attacks hypnotised victims.
Paralysing bite: Victim must save versus paralysis or be paralysed for 1d4 turns.
Monsters.description: Giant snake skeletons (10‚Äô long) with a snake-fanged human skull for a head. Created by powerful magic-users or clerics for a specific purpose (e.g. to guard treasures or to assassinate a victim).

special_abilities: Burning smoke: Breathe out a choking cloud of burning smoke. Anyone in melee with a nightmare must save versus poison or suffer ‚Äì2 to attack and damage rolls against the monster.
Steed: Sometimes act as a steed for powerful undead (e.g. demonic knight, lich, spectre, vampire).
Monsters.description: Intelligent, demonic horses with glowing red eyes, flaming nostrils, and hooves like smouldering embers.

special_abilities: Shy: Will try to charm intruders, rather than entering combat.
Weapons: Daggers and small tridents (as spears).

Charm: 10 nixies together can cast a charm to enchant a victim to serve them for one year. Save versus spells or be charmed: move towards the nixies (resisting those who try to prevent it); defend the nixies; obey the nixies‚Äô commands (if understood); unable to cast spells or use magic items; unable to harm the nixies. Killing the nixies breaks the charm.
Summon giant bass: Each nixie can summon one fish to aid in combat (see Giant Bass).
Bestow water breathing: Can cast upon charmed slaves. Lasts for one day, then must be refreshed.
Monsters.description: 3‚Äô tall sprites that appear as attractive women with blueish, greenish, or greyish skin. Lair in the deepest parts of rivers and lakes.

special_abilities: Class: Usually treated as 3rd level fighters, but may be of any class and level.
Monsters.description: Powerful humans with noble titles (e.g. Count, Duke, Knight, etc.). Dwell in castles.
Accompanied by up to ten 1st level fighters (retainers).
Accompanied by a 2nd level fighter (a squire).

special_abilities: Mounted: On riding horses or (in the desert) on camels.
Arms (desert): 50% of the group have: leather armour, shield, lance; 30% have: chainmail, shield, lance; 20% have: leather armour, shortbow.

Arms (steppes): 50% of group have: leather armour, shortbow; 20% have: leather armour, shield, lance; 20% have: chainmail, shortbow; 10% have: chain mail, shield, lance, and may be mounted on a war horse.
Hoard: Only have treasure type A in the camp.
Traders: Often carry trade route tales of faraway lands.
Monsters.description: Superstitious tribes who wander steppes and desert regions, living in tents or temporary huts. Demeanour depends on the tribe: some are warlike, others peaceful.
50% chance of a cleric (9th level) in a nomad camp.
A 5th level fighter is present for every 100 nomads in a camp.
25% chance of a magic-user (8th level) in a nomad camp.
For every 25 nomads, there is a 2nd level fighter leader.
For every 40 nomads, there is a 4th level fighter leader.
Tribal chief (8th level fighter) for nomad camps.

special_abilities: Gaining XP: Must select a character class after gaining XP on an adventure.
Monsters.description: Non-adventuring humans without a character class. Artists, beggars, children, craftspeople, farmers, fishermen, housewives, scholars, slaves.

special_abilities: Immunity: Unharmed by all attacks except cold or fire.
Division: Lightning or attacks with weapons cause the jelly to divide into 1d4+1 2HD jellies that do half damage.

Acid: After a successful attack, sticks to the victim and exudes acid. The acid inflicts 2d6 damage per round to flesh and destroys cloth, leather, or wood in one round. (Stone and metal are unaffected.)
Seep: Can squeeze through small holes and cracks.
Monsters.description: Giant, ochre amoeboids.

special_abilities: Immunity: Unharmed by all attacks except cold or fire.

Acid: After a successful attack, sticks to the victim and exudes acid. The acid inflicts 2d6 damage per round to flesh and destroys cloth, leather, or wood in one round. (Stone and metal are unaffected.)
Seep: Can squeeze through small holes and cracks.
Monsters.description: Resulting from an Ochre Jelly division, these 2HD jellies do half damage.

special_abilities: Sack: Outside of the lair, carry a sack containing 1d6 √ó 100gp.
Hate neanderthals: Attack on sight.
Monsters.description: Frightful humanoids, 8‚Äì10‚Äô tall, dressed in animal hides. Often dwell in caves.

special_abilities: Hate the sun: ‚Äì1 to hit in full daylight.
Weapons: Prefer axes, clubs, spears, or swords. Only leaders can use mechanical weapons (e.g. crossbows, catapults).
Craven: Afraid of larger or stronger-looking creatures, though leaders may force them to fight.
Giant companions: For every 20 orcs, there is a 1-in-6 chance of an ogre accompanying them. There is a 1-in-10 chance of a troll living in the lair.
Tribal: Orcs of different tribes may fight among themselves, unless their leaders command them not to. Each tribe has its own lair and has as many females as males, and two whelps per two adults.
Mercenaries: Orcs may be hired to fight in Chaotic armies. They delight in wanton killing and razing of settlements.
Monsters.description: Ugly, bad-tempered, animalistic humanoids who live underground and are active at night. Sadistic bullies who hate other living creatures and delight in killing.

special_abilities: The chieftain gains a +2 bonus to damage rolls.
Monsters.description: A 4HD (15hp) chieftain rules an orc tribe.

special_abilities: The leader gains a +1 bonus to damage rolls.
Monsters.description: Groups are led by an orc with 8 hit points. Leaders have defeated other orcs in combat to gain their position.

special_abilities: Disease: Victims must save versus poison or contract a disease that is fatal in 1d12 days.
Light sensitivity: Suffer a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls and a ‚Äì1 penalty to AC when in bright light (daylight, continual light).
Telepathic: Can communicate non-verbally with any sentient creature.
Symbiotic: Often live in partnership with a powerful monster, living off its dung and the carcasses of its victims.
Predatory Otyughs: Rumours tell of rare, highly intelligent, predatory Otyughs.
Monsters.description: Aggressive, semi-intelligent, hulking (8‚Äô around) monstrosities with three stumpy legs, eyes on a long tentacle stalk, a sphincter-like mouth lined with fangs, and two razor-edged tentacles. Lurk underground in piles of dung or carrion, which they consume. Crave fresh meat.

special_abilities: Disease: Victims must save versus poison or contract a disease that is fatal in 1d12 days.
Light sensitivity: Suffer a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls and a ‚Äì1 penalty to AC when in bright light (daylight, continual light).
Telepathic: Can communicate non-verbally with any sentient creature.
Symbiotic: Often live in partnership with a powerful monster, living off its dung and the carcasses of its victims.
Predatory Otyughs: Rumours tell of rare, highly intelligent, predatory Otyughs.

special_abilities: Bear hug: If a victim is hit by both paws in the same round, the owl bear hugs for an extra 2d8 automatic damage.
Monsters.description: Huge (8‚Äô tall, 1,500 pounds), ill-tempered, carnivorous bear-like creature with the face of an owl. Owl bears are found in dense forests and underground.

special_abilities: Pursuit: Always pursue prey that flees.
Favoured prey: Often develop a taste for a certain type of meat (this may include humans!), hunting that creature with preference.
Inquisitive: May follow PCs out of curiosity.
Monsters.description: High-speed hunters that live in plains and forests.

special_abilities: Hate hippogriffs: Natural enemies.
Mount: Can carry a human-sized rider.
Training: If captured when young, will serve Lawful characters.
Monsters.description: Semi-intelligent winged horses that are wilful and timid.

special_abilities: Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Killing a victim: When a victim is killed, the peryton rips out their heart and flies away.
Monsters.description: Weird monsters with the body, talons, and wings of a giant eagle, the head and great antlers of a stag, and the fangs of a wolf. Dwell in mountains. Prey upon humans and their ilk.

special_abilities: Fiery aura: All within 20‚Äô suffer 6d6 damage per round. Phoenix fire is of such intensity that magical protection from fire is ineffective.
Magic resistance: +2 to saving throws.
Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Fire immunity: Unharmed by magical and non-magical fire.
Spell immunity: Unaffected by charm and hold spells.

Upon death: Disappear in a 20‚Äô radius ball of ash and fire, inflicting 1d10 √ó 10 damage (save versus breath for half). Phoenix fire is of such intensity that magical protection from fire is ineffective.
Resurrection: 1 round after death, returns to life from its ashes and flees.
Feathers: Phoenix feathers are highly magical. Each is worth up to 25,000gp.
Monsters.description: Highly magical giant orange-red eagles (20‚Äô wingspan) wreathed in searing flame. Dwell in remote areas guarding magical shrines, portals, tombs, etc. Only violent if attacked.
Monsters.habitat: Remote areas (guarding shrines, portals, tombs, etc.)

special_abilities: Blend in with stone: Indistinguishable from normal stalactites.
Drop: Sensitive to sound and heat. Attack a victim directly below by dropping from the ceiling. Creep back up to the ceiling if the attack misses.
Monsters.description: Non-intelligent, carnivorous monsters that hang from cavern ceilings, resembling stalactites. 2‚Äô to 6‚Äô long.

special_abilities: Blend in with stone: Indistinguishable from normal stalactites.
Drop: Sensitive to sound and heat. Attack a victim directly below by dropping from the ceiling. Creep back up to the ceiling if the attack misses.
Monsters.description: Non-intelligent, carnivorous monsters that hang from cavern ceilings, resembling stalactites. 2‚Äô to 6‚Äô long.

special_abilities: Blend in with stone: Indistinguishable from normal stalactites.
Drop: Sensitive to sound and heat. Attack a victim directly below by dropping from the ceiling. Creep back up to the ceiling if the attack misses.
Monsters.description: Non-intelligent, carnivorous monsters that hang from cavern ceilings, resembling stalactites. 2‚Äô to 6‚Äô long.

special_abilities: Blend in with stone: Indistinguishable from normal stalactites.
Drop: Sensitive to sound and heat. Attack a victim directly below by dropping from the ceiling. Creep back up to the ceiling if the attack misses.
Monsters.description: Non-intelligent, carnivorous monsters that hang from cavern ceilings, resembling stalactites. 2‚Äô to 6‚Äô long.

special_abilities: Ships and crew: Depends where encountered. Rivers or lakes: 1d8 river boats (1d2 √ó 10 pirates each); coastal waters: 1d6 small galleys (1d3+1 √ó 10 pirates each); any: 1d4 longships (1d3+2 √ó 10 pirates each); ocean: 1d3 small warships (1d5+3 √ó 10 pirates each).
Arms: 50% of group have: leather armour, sword; 35% have: leather armour, sword, crossbow; 15% have: chainmail, sword.
Treacherous: Will attack other pirates, if they can profit from it.
Prisoners: 25% chance of 1d3 prisoners to be ransomed.
Treasure: Divided between vessels. Instead of carrying with them, they may have a map to where it is buried.
Havens: Lawless, fortified, coastal towns may act as a haven for pirates.
Monsters.description: Sailors who make a living by raiding coastal settlements, robbing other ships, and illegal slaving. Typically ply the open seas. Renowned for their ruthless and evil ways.

special_abilities: 75% chance of a magic-user (level 1d2+8).
Monsters.description: Fleets of 300 or more pirates are led by a pirate lord (11th level fighter).
For every 30 pirates, there is a 4th level fighter.
For every 50 pirates, and for each ship, there is a 5th level fighter.
For every 100 pirates, and per fleet, there is an 8th level fighter.

special_abilities: Infravision: 60‚Äô. (Pits in the head allow heat sense.)
Initiative: Always gains initiative (no roll), due to special senses.
Poison: Causes death (save vs poison).
Monsters.description: 5‚Äô long snakes with grey/green scales.

special_abilities: Invisible: Naturally invisible, but may choose to reveal themselves. May remain invisible when attacking: cannot be attacked in the first round; in subsequent rounds, may be attacked at ‚Äì2 to hit (locatable by faint shadows and air movement).
Surprise: Always surprise, if invisible.
Limited flight: Small wings only allow 3 turns of flight. Must rest 1 turn after flying.
Monsters.description: 1‚Äì2‚Äô tall humanoids with insectoid wings. Distant relatives of elves.

special_abilities: Bear hug: If a victim is hit by both claw attacks in the same round, the bear hugs for an extra 2d8 automatic damage.
Swimming: Excellent swimmers.
Snow walk: Wide paws allow running on the surface of snow without sinking.
Monsters.description: Aggressive, white-furred bears that stand 11‚Äô tall and live in cold regions. Favour eating fish.

special_abilities: Undead: Immune to effects that affect living creatures (e.g. poison). Immune to mind-affecting or mind-reading spells (e.g. charm, hold, sleep).
Surprise: Always surprise, unless PCs can see invisible.
Hurled objects: Range 30‚Äô. Can only throw objects which are nearby.
Mundane damage immunity: Only harmed by silver weapons or magic.
Attacking a poltergeist: Location can be deduced from the source of thrown objects. Attack rolls suffer a ‚Äì4 penalty.
Monsters.description: Invisible, incorporeal spirits which haunt the place of their death. Lift small objects and hurl them at intruders.

special_abilities: Surprise: On a 1‚Äì4, due to chameleon-like ability to blend in with surroundings.
Poison: Induces a comatose, near death state for 1d6 days (save versus poison). Victim appears dead, except to very close inspection.
Magic resistance: +2 bonus to all saving throws against magic.
Telepathy: Communicate telepathically within 30‚Äô.
Companion: Sometimes become a companion for a lawful adventurer. Able to telepathically transmit senses to the companion, up to 240‚Äô distant.
Monsters.description: Intelligent, miniature (1‚Äì2‚Äô long), winged dragons with a sting-tipped tail and rusty red scales. Dwell in small caves or hollowed out trees.
Monsters.habitat: Small caves or hollowed out trees

Monsters.description: Often found in Lost World regions. Wingspan of up to 50‚Äô. Highly aggressive; often prey on humanoids.
Often found in Lost World regions. 8‚Äì10‚Äô wingspan. Prey on small to medium animals, but will attack humanoids, if very hungry.

special_abilities: Swallow whole: A bite attack roll of natural 20, or 4 or more than the target number required, indicates that a human-sized (or smaller) victim is swallowed. Inside the worm‚Äôs belly: suffer 3d6 damage per round (until the worm dies); may attack with sharp weapons at ‚Äì4 to hit; body digested in 6 turns after death.
Poison: Causes death (save vs poison).
In restricted spaces: May not always be able to bite and sting at once.
Monsters.description: Gigantic, slimy worms with bodies 100‚Äô long and 8‚Äì10‚Äô thick. Bore tunnels through the earth and come to the surface to eat other creatures.

special_abilities: Cloak true form: Can read the minds of those they encounter then cloak their true form with an illusion of a creature or type of person deemed friendly.
Spell immunity: Immune to all spells of 1st to 3rd level.
Mundane damage immunity: Can only be harmed by magical attacks.
Spell casting: Cast spells as a 5th level magic-user and a 3rd level cleric.
Vulnerability: A hit by a blessed crossbow bolt kills a rakshasa.
Groups: A single male will often be encountered with multiple females.
Monsters.description: Highly intelligent evil spirits that take the form of feline humanoids, with the head of a great cat (e.g. tiger, panther), eerie reversed hands, and cruel claws. Prefer a diet of human flesh. Use their powers of illusion to gain the trust of people, then attack. Dwell in hot climes.

special_abilities: Disease: Bite has a 1-in-20 chance of infecting the target (save versus poison). The disease has a 1-in-4 chance of being deadly (die in 1d6 days). Otherwise, the victim is sick and bedridden for one month.
Afraid of fire: Will flee fire, unless forced to fight by summoner.
Attacking in water: May attack without penalty; excellent swimmers.
Pack: Each group of 5‚Äì10 rats attacks as a pack. Each pack makes a single attack roll against one creature.
Engulf: The creature attacked must save versus death or fall prone, unable to attack until able to stand up again.
Monsters.description: Multitudinous, disease-ridden rodents that will eat anything. Avoid contact with humans, but may attack if defending their nest or if summoned and commanded by magic (e.g. see Wererat). Swarming packs of 6‚Äù to 2‚Äô long individuals, with brown or grey fur.

special_abilities: Breath weapon: 90‚Äô long cone of fire.
Language and spells: 50%; 3 √ó 1st level, 3 √ó 2nd level, 3 √ó 3rd level.
Sleeping: 10%.
Monsters.description: Dwell in hills and mountains.

special_abilities: Swallow whole: A bite attack roll of 20 indicates that a human-sized (or smaller) victim is swallowed. This is instantly fatal, due to the internal fires.
Melt weapons: A weapon that hits has a 1-in-4 chance of contacting the red hot back and instantly melting. Magical weapons are unaffected.
Avoiding the back: Trying not to hit the red hot back incurs a ‚Äì2 penalty to attack rolls.
Nests: A pair of remorhaz is occasionally encountered in their lair with a clutch of 1d2 eggs. Each egg is worth 5,000gp.
Monsters.description: Predatory, many-legged worm-like monsters with long necks, horrid, crushing mandibles, and compound eyes. Icy blue in colour, with scaly plates along the back which glow red hot. Dwell in frozen wastes, sustained by the heat of their internal fires.
